LittlevGL is a free and open-source graphics library providing everything you need to create embedded GUI with easy-to-use graphical elements, beautiful visual effects and low memory footprint.

\chapter{主要特点}
\label{\detokenize{index:id1}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
强大的块构建能力：按钮，图表，列表，滑动条，图片等

\item {} 
高级图形效果：动画，反锯齿，透明度，平滑滚动

\item {} 
多种输入设备支持： 触摸板，鼠标，键盘，编码器等

\item {} 
支持多语言的UTF-8编码

\item {} 
Multi-display support, i.e. use more TFT, monochrome displays simultaneously

\item {} 
完全的自定义图形组件功能

\item {} 
Hardware independent to use with any microcontroller or display

\item {} 
Scalable to operate with little memory (64 kB Flash, 16 kB RAM)

\item {} 
OS, External memory and GPU supported but not required

\item {} 
仅仅单个帧缓冲设备就可以呈现高级视觉特效

\item {} 
使用C编写以获得最大兼容性(兼容C++)

\item {} 
无需拥有嵌入式硬件设备，在PC上的模拟器开始设计嵌入式GUI

\item {} 
为加速GUI设计，提供教程,、案例和主题

\item {} 
在线和离线文档

\item {} 
基于自由和开源的MIT协议

\end{itemize}


\chapter{要求}
\label{\detokenize{index:id2}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
16、32或64位的单片机（微控制器）或处理器

\item {} 
推荐使用\textgreater{} 16 MHz时钟速度

\item {} 
Flash/ROM: 为了运行让最基本的组件运行起来，需要\textgreater{} 64 kB (推荐\textgreater{} 180 kB)

\item {} 
RAM:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
静态RAM 使用: \textasciitilde{}8..16 kB ，取决于使用的功能对象类型

\item {} 
栈内存: \textgreater{} 2kB (推荐\textgreater{} 4 kB)

\item {} 
动态数据 (推内存): \textgreater{} 4 KB (当使用多种不同的对象，推荐\textgreater{} 16 kB).
在\sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}设置 \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MEM\_SIZE}} 。

\item {} 
显示缓冲:  \textgreater{} \sphinxstyleemphasis{“水平分辨率”} 像素 (推荐\textgreater{} 10 × \sphinxstyleemphasis{“水平分辨率”} )

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
C99或更新的编译器

\item {} 
基础C (or C++) 知识: \sphinxhref{https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cprogramming/c\_pointers.htm}{指针}, \sphinxhref{https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cprogramming/c\_structures.htm}{结构体}, \sphinxhref{https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/callbacks-in-c/}{回调}.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{请注意内存占用可能非常依赖于构架、编译器和编译选项。}


\chapter{常见问题}
\label{\detokenize{index:id3}}

\section{从哪来开始？}
\label{\detokenize{index:id4}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
总体概览LittlevGL请访问\sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com}{littlevgl.com}

\item {} 
Go to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{get-started/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Get started}}}} section to try Live demos in you browser, learn about the Simulator(s) and learn the basics of LittlevGL.

\item {} 
A detailed porting guide can be found in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} section.

\item {} 
To learn how LittlevGL works go to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Overview}}}}.

\item {} 
阅读教程或者分享你的见解请前往 \sphinxhref{https://blog.littlevgl.com}{博客}

\item {} 
To see the source code of the library check it on GitHub: \sphinxurl{https://github.com/littlevgl/lvgl/}.

\end{itemize}


\section{在哪里我可以问问题?}
\label{\detokenize{index:id5}}
可以在论坛上问问题: \sphinxurl{https://forum.littlevgl.com/}.

我们使用 \sphinxhref{https://github.com/littlevgl/lvgl/issues}{GitHub 问题}和库开发相关的问题，因此你应该仅仅在上面问与库开发紧密相关的的问题。 （即普通问题，如使用问题应该在论坛上问，库的设计问题或者bug可以在Github上提）


\section{是否支持我的单片机或硬件?}
\label{\detokenize{index:id6}}
每个可以通过并口、SPI、RGB接口或者其他设备驱动一个屏幕并且能够满足 {\hyperref[\detokenize{index:Requirements}]{\emph{需求}}}的单片机都支持LittlevGL。
它包含
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
“普通”单片机如 STM32F, STM32H, NXP Kinetis, LPC, iMX, dsPIC33, PIC32 等等.

\item {} 
蓝牙, GSM, WiFi 模块如 Nordic NRF 和 Espressif ESP32

\item {} 
包含在一些单片机的Linux帧缓冲设备，如树莓派上的的/dev/fb0

\item {} 
and anything else with a strong enough MCU and a periphery to drive a display

\end{itemize}


\section{是否支持我的屏幕?}
\label{\detokenize{index:id7}}
LittlevGL needs just one simple driver to copy an array of pixels to a given area of the display. If you can do this with your display then you can use that display with LittlevGL.
它包含
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
16或24位色彩深度的TFT屏幕

\item {} 
带有HDMI端口的监视器

\item {} 
小的单色显示屏

\item {} 
灰阶显示设备

\item {} 
LED矩阵

\item {} 
或其他任何你可以控制像素颜色或状态的显示设备

\end{itemize}

在 {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/display::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{移植}}}} 章节查看更多内容


\section{LittlevGL是免费的吗？我该如何在商业产品中使用它呢？}
\label{\detokenize{index:id8}}
LittlevGL伴随着MIT协议，这意味着你可以以任何目的去下载和使用它而无需做出任何义务。


\section{什么都没有显示，我的显示驱动没有被调用，我漏掉了什么？}
\label{\detokenize{index:id9}}
确保你在中断上调用了 \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(x)}} 并且 在 main方法的\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{while(1)}} 中调用了\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}}。

更多请查看 {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/tick::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Tick}}}} 和{\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{任务处理}}}} 章节。


\section{为什么显示驱动只被调用了一次？只刷新了显示屏的上半部分。}
\label{\detokenize{index:id10}}
Be sure you are calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_flush\_ready(drv)}} at the end of you \sphinxstyleemphasis{display flush callback}.

\section{为什么我的屏幕的颜色有点不对劲？}
\label{\detokenize{index:id12}}
可能LittlevGL的色彩格式不和你的显示设备兼容，检查\sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} 的 \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}}。

如果你使用的是16位颜色的SPI (或者其他面向字节的) 接口，可能你需要在 \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} 设置 \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_16\_SWAP  1}}，它的作用是将高位和低位的字节互换。


\section{如何提高我的UI速度?}
\label{\detokenize{index:ui}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
启用编译优化(gcc -O)

\item {} 
增加显示缓冲的大小

\item {} 
使用双显示缓冲和在后台使用DMA（或类似的外围设备）刷新缓冲

\item {} 
Increase the clock speed of the SPI or Parallel port if you use them to drive the display

\item {} 
如果你的显示设备有SPI端口，请考虑使用并行模式，因为这样可以提高吞吐量

\item {} 
保持显示缓冲在内部RAM (不是外部SRAM) 因为 LittlevGL 会频繁使用它所以它应该拥有较小的访问时间

\end{itemize}


\section{如何减少 flash/ROM 使用量?}
\label{\detokenize{index:flash-rom}}
你可以在\sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}关闭不必要的功能（如动画、文件系统和GPU等等）和对象类型

如果你使用GCC你可以加上
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-fdata-sections -ffunction-sections}} 编译标志

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-{-}gc-sections}} 链接标志

\end{itemize}

来去除无用的函数和变量
{}`


\section{怎么减少 RAM  使用量}
\label{\detokenize{index:ram}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
降低\sphinxstyleemphasis{显示缓冲} 的大小

\item {} 
减少\sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}中的\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MEM\_SIZE}}，这个是你创建按钮、标签和其他对象时使用的内存大小

\item {} 
To work with lower \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MEM\_SIZE}} you can create the objects only when required and deleted them when they are not required anymore.

\end{itemize}


\section{怎么在我的操作系统上使用?}
\label{\detokenize{index:id13}}
为了在拥有中断的操作系统上使用，为了保护LittlevGL，你可以与互斥锁一同调用相关函数，请查看 {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/os::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{操作系统}}}} 章节获取更多内容

这里有多种方法为LittlevGL做出贡献:

\subsection{开始使用}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/index::doc}}

\subsubsection{在线演示}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/live-demo:id1}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/live-demo::doc}}
你可以在不下载安装LittlevGL的情况下了解它具体长什么样子
你可以轻松的在你的浏览器上查看这些已经制备好的用户界面

前往 \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/live-demo}{在线演示} 页面选择你感兴趣的演示项目。


\subsubsection{PC上的模拟器}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:pc}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator::doc}}
你可以通过\sphinxstylestrong{使用你的PC}来尝试LittlevGL而无需任何开发板，你可以在PC上编写、运行代码和在监视器上查看运行结果。这种方式是跨平台的，Windows, Linux 和 OSX都支持。
这些代码都是可移植的，你可以轻易的复制运行到你的嵌入式硬件设备上。

同样的，模拟器也对反馈bug非常有帮助，因为它意味着每个用户的通用平台，所以最好在模拟器上用你的代码复现bug反馈到\sphinxhref{https://forum.littlevgl.com}{论坛}。


\paragraph{选择一个IDE}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:ide}}
模拟器已经一直到多个IDE中，选择你最喜欢的IDE，阅读GitHub上的README，下载并在IDE上加载。



下面详细地描述了Eclipse CDT的配置指南


\paragraph{配置 Eclipse CDT}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:eclipse-cdt}}

\subparagraph{安装 Eclipse CDT}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:id1}}
Eclipse CDT 是 C/C++ IDE，你也可以使用其他IDE，但在这个教程里我们呈现如何配置Eclipse CDT

Eclipse 是基于Java的软件，因此请确保 \sphinxstylestrong{Java 运行时环境（JRE）} 已经安装在你的系统上

在类Debian发行版上运行 (如：Ubuntu): \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt-get install default-jre}}

你可以从这里下载Eclipse’s CDT: \sphinxhref{http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/}{https://eclipse.org/cdt/}，运行安装器从列表中选择 \sphinxstyleemphasis{Eclipse CDT}


\subparagraph{安装 SDL 2}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:sdl-2}}
PC模拟器使用  \sphinxhref{https://www.libsdl.org/download-2.0.php}{SDL 2} 跨平台库来模拟 TFT 显示设备和触摸板。


\subparagraph{Linux}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:linux}}
在 \sphinxstylestrong{Linux}  上你可以通过终端简单的安装SDL2：
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
找到当前的SDL2版本: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apt-cache search libsdl2 (例如 libsdl2-2.0-0)}}

\item {} 
安装 SDL2: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt-get install libsdl2-2.0-0}} (替代你找到的版本)

\item {} 
安装SDL2开发包: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt-get install libsdl2-dev}}

\item {} 
如果基本编译库build essentials尚未安装: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt-get install build-essential}}

\end{enumerate}


\subparagraph{Windows}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:windows}}
如果你使用的是 \sphinxstylestrong{Windows} 首先你需要安装 MinGW (\sphinxhref{http://mingw-w64.org/doku.php/download}{64 位版本})，然后再按以下步骤安装SDL2：
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
下载SDL的开发库前往 \sphinxurl{https://www.libsdl.org/download-2.0.php} 并 \sphinxstyleemphasis{下载库: SDL2-devel-2.0.5-mingw.tar.gz}

\item {} 
解压并前往 \sphinxstyleemphasis{x86\_64-w64-mingw32} 文件夹(64 位的MinGW) 或 \sphinxstyleemphasis{i686-w64-mingw32} ( 32 位的MinGW)

\item {} 
复制 \_…\sphinxstyleemphasis{mingw32/include/SDL2} 文件夹到 \sphinxstyleemphasis{C:/MinGW/…/x86\_64-w64-mingw32/include}

\item {} 
复制\_…\sphinxstyleemphasis{mingw32/lib/} 中的内容到 \sphinxstyleemphasis{C:/MinGW/…/x86\_64-w64-mingw32/lib}

\item {} 
复制\_…\sphinxstyleemphasis{mingw32/bin/SDL2.dll} 到\_\{eclipse\_worksapce\}/pc\_simulator/Debug/\_，请在Eclipse完成安装后执行

\end{enumerate}

请注意：如果你使用的是 \sphinxstylestrong{Microsoft Visual Studio}而不是 Eclipse，那么你不需要安装 MinGW.


\subparagraph{OSX}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:osx}}
你可以容易的通过brew在 \sphinxstylestrong{OSX} 上安装SDL2 ：\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{brew install sdl2}}

如果没有用我建议查看\sphinxhref{http://lazyfoo.net/tutorials/SDL/01\_hello\_SDL/index.php}{这个教程} 来开始使用SDL。


\subparagraph{预配置项目}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:id2}}
一个预配置的图形库项目（基于最新的版本）总是可用
你可以在 \sphinxhref{https://github.com/littlevgl/proj\_pc}{GitHub} 或 \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/download}{下载} 页面中找到它
(这个项目是为Eclipse CDT配置的)


\subparagraph{添加预配置项目到Eclipse CDT}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:id3}}
运行Eclipse CDT，他会显示一个关于 \sphinxstylestrong{workspace path}的对话框，在接受之前复制 (并解压) 已下载好的预配置项目到上面的路径中，现在你可以接受这个workspace path。当然你也可以修改这个路径并复制项目到你自定义的路径中

关闭开始窗口并前往 \sphinxstylestrong{File-\textgreater{}Import} 选择 \sphinxstylestrong{General-\textgreater{}Existing project into Workspace}. \sphinxstylestrong{选择项目根目录} 并点击 \sphinxstylestrong{Finish}

在 \sphinxstylestrong{Windows} 你必须做这两件额外的事：
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
复制 \sphinxstylestrong{SDL2.dll} 到项目的Debug目录

\item {} 
右击项目的 -\textgreater{} Project properties -\textgreater{} C/C++ Build -\textgreater{} Settings -\textgreater{} Libraries -\textgreater{} Add … 并在 \sphinxstyleemphasis{mingw32} 上添加 SDLmain 和 SDL。 (这个顺序非常重要: mingw32, SDLmain, SDL)

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{编译并运行}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:id4}}
Now you are ready to run the LittlevGL Graphics Library on your PC. Click on the Hammer Icon on the top menu bar to Build the project. If you have done everything right you will not get any errors. Note that on some systems additional steps might be required to “see” SDL 2 from Eclipse but in most of cases the configurations in the downloaded project is enough.

在编译成功后点击在上方菜单栏中Play按钮来运行项目，现在一个窗口应该出现在你的屏幕中央

现在所有东西已经准备好，你可以开始在你PC上实践使用LittlevGL图形库了。


\subsubsection{Quick overview}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:quick-overview}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview::doc}}
Here you can learn the most important things about LittlevGL.
You should read it first to get a general impression and read the detailed {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Overview}}}} sections after that.


\paragraph{Add LittlevGL into your project}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:add-littlevgl-into-your-project}}
The steps below show how to setup LittlevGL on an embedded system with a display and a touchpad.
You can use the {\hyperref[\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Simulators}}}} to get ready to use projects which can be run on your PC.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/download}{Download} or \sphinxhref{https://github.com/littlevgl/lvgl}{Clone} the library

\item {} 
Copy the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl}} folder into your project

\item {} 
Copy \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl/lv\_conf\_templ.h}} as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_conf.h}} next to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl}} folder and set at least \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_HOR\_RES\_MAX}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_VER\_RES\_MAX}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}}.

\item {} 
Include \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl/lvgl.h}} where you need to use LittlevGL related functions.

\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(x)}} every \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}} milliseconds \sphinxstylestrong{in a Timer or Task} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}} should be between 1 and 10). It is required for the internal timing of LittlevGL.

\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_init()}}

\item {} 
Create a display buffer for LittlevGL

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}buf\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{buf}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}MAX} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}                     \PYG{c+cm}{/*Declare a buffer for 10 lines*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}buf\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{buf}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}MAX} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Initialize the display buffer*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Implement and register a function which can \sphinxstylestrong{copy a pixel array} to an area of your display:

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Descriptor of a display driver*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Basic initialization*/}
\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{flush\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}flush}\PYG{p}{;}    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set your driver function*/}
\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{buffer} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Assign the buffer to the display*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Finally register the driver*/}
    
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}flush}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{disp}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}area\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{color\PYGZus{}p}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k+kt}{int32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{for}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{y1}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{y2}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{for}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}pixel}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{color\PYGZus{}p}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Put a pixel to the display.*/}
            \PYG{n}{color\PYGZus{}p}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}flush\PYGZus{}ready}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{disp}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/* Indicate you are ready with the flushing*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
    
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Implement and register a function which can \sphinxstylestrong{read an input device}. E.g. for a touch pad:

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}             \PYG{c+cm}{/*Descriptor of a input device driver*/}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}POINTER}\PYG{p}{;}    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Touch pad is a pointer\PYGZhy{}like device*/}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}touchpad\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set your driver function*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Finally register the driver*/}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}touchpad\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{indev}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}coord\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}coord\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}y} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Save the state and save the pressed coordinate*/}
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{touchpad\PYGZus{}is\PYGZus{}pressed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{?} \PYG{n+nl}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR} \PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;} 
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{touchpad\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}xy}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
   
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the coordinates (if released use the last pressed coordinates)*/}
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{point}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{point}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}y}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Return {}`false{}` because we are not buffering and no more data to read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} periodically every few milliseconds in the main \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{while(1)}} loop, in Timer interrupt or in an Operation system task.
It will redraw the screen if required, handle input devices etc.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Learn the basics}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:learn-the-basics}}

\subparagraph{Objects (Widgets)}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:objects-widgets}}
The graphical elements like Buttons, Labels, Sliders, Charts etc are called objects in LittelvGL. Go to {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Object types}}}} to see the full list of available types.

Every object has a parent object. The child object moves with the parent and if you delete the parent the children will be deleted too. Children can be visible only on their parent.

The \sphinxstyleemphasis{screen} are the “root” parents. To get the current screen call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}}.

You can create a new object with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_\textless{}type\textgreater{}\_create(parent, obj\_to\_copy)}}. It will return an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_t *}} variable which should be used as a reference to the object to set its parameters.
The first parameter is the desired \sphinxstyleemphasis{parent}, te second parameters can be an object to copy (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} is unused).
For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{slider1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To set some basic attribute \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_\textless{}paramters\_name\textgreater{}(obj, \textless{}value\textgreater{})}} function can be used. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}y}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{200}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The objects has type specific parameters too which can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_\textless{}type\textgreater{}\_set\_\textless{}paramters\_name\textgreater{}(obj, \textless{}value\textgreater{})}} functions. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}value}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{slider1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{70}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}ANIM\PYGZus{}ON}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To see the full API visit the documentation of the object types or the related header file (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl/src/lv\_objx/lv\_slider.h}}).


\subparagraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:styles}}
Styles can be assigned to the objects to changed their appearance. A style describes the appearance of rectangle-like objects (like a button or slider), texts, images and lines at once.

You can create a new style like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Declare a new style. Should be {}`static{}`*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}copy}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}plain}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Copy a buil\PYGZhy{}in style*/}
\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{body}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{main\PYGZus{}color} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}RED}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Main color*/}
\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{body}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{grad\PYGZus{}color} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mh}{0xffd83c}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Gradient color (orange)*/}
\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{body}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{radius} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{color} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}hex3}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mh}{0x0F0}\PYG{p}{)}        \PYG{c+cm}{/*Label color (green)*/}
\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{font} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}dejavu\PYGZus{}22}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Change font*/}
\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To set a new style for an object use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_\textless{}type\textgreater{}set\_style(obj, LV\_\textless{}TYPE\textgreater{}\_STYLE\_\textless{}NAME\textgreater{}, \&my\_style)}} functions. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{slider1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SLIDER\PYGZus{}STYLE\PYGZus{}BG}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{slider\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{slider1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SLIDER\PYGZus{}STYLE\PYGZus{}INDIC}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{slider\PYGZus{}indic\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{slider1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SLIDER\PYGZus{}STYLE\PYGZus{}KNOB}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{slider\PYGZus{}knob\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If an object’s style is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} then it will inherit its parent’s style. For example, the labels’ style are \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} by default. If you place them on a button then they will use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}} properties from the button’s style.

Learn more in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/style::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Style overview}}}} section.


\subparagraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:events}}
Events are used to inform the user if something has happened with an object. You can assign a callback to an object which will be called if the object is clicked, released, dragged, being deleted etc. It should look like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Assign a callback to the button*/}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}

\subsubsection{Micropython}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:micropython}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython::doc}}

\paragraph{What is Micropython?}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:what-is-micropython}}
\sphinxhref{http://micropython.org/}{Micropython} is Python for microcontrollers.With Micropython you can write Python3 code and run it on bare metal architectures with limited resources.


\subparagraph{Micropython highlights}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:micropython-highlights}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Compact} - fit and run within just 256k of code space and 16k of RAM. No OS is needed, although you can also run it with OS, if you want.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Compatible} - strives to be as compatible as possible with normal Python (known as CPython)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Verstile} - Supports many architectures (x86, x86-64, ARM, ARM Thumb, Xtensa)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Interactive} - No need for the compile-flash-boot cycle. With the REPL (interactive prompt) you can type commands and execute them immediately, run scripts etc.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Popular} - Many platforms are supported. User base is growing bigger.Notable forks: \sphinxhref{https://github.com/micropython/micropython}{MicroPython}, \sphinxhref{https://github.com/adafruit/circuitpython}{CircuitPython}, \sphinxhref{https://github.com/loboris/MicroPython\_ESP32\_psRAM\_LoBo}{MicroPython\_ESP32\_psRAM\_LoBo}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Embedded Oriented} - Comes with modules specifically for embedded systems, such as the \sphinxhref{https://docs.micropython.org/en/latest/library/machine.html\#classes}{machine module} for accessing low-level hardware (I/O pins, ADC, UART, SPI, I2C, RTC, Timers etc.)

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\paragraph{Why Micropython + LittlevGL?}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:why-micropython-littlevgl}}
Micropython today \sphinxhref{https://forum.micropython.org/viewtopic.php?f=18\&t=5543}{does not have a good high-level GUI library}.LittlevGL is a good high-level GUI library, it’s implemented in C and its API is in C.LittlevGL is an \sphinxhref{https://blog.littlevgl.com/2018-12-13/extend-lvgl-objects}{Object Oriented Component Based} library, which seems a natural candidate to map into a higher level language, such as Python.


\subparagraph{Here are some advantages of using LittlevGL in Micropython:}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:here-are-some-advantages-of-using-littlevgl-in-micropython}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Develop GUI in Python, a very popular high level language. Use paradigms such as Object Oriented Programming.

\item {} 
GUI development requires multiple iterations to get things right.With C, each iteration consists of \sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Change code}} \textgreater{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Build}} \textgreater{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Flash}} \textgreater{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Run}}}.In Micropython it’s just \sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Change code}} \textgreater{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Run}}}. You can even run commands interactively using the \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Read\%E2\%80\%93eval\%E2\%80\%93print\_loop}{REPL} (the interactive prompt)

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Micropython + LittlevGL could be used for:}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:micropython-littlevgl-could-be-used-for}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Fast prototyping GUI.

\item {} 
Shorten the cycle of changing and fine-tuning the GUI.

\item {} 
Model the GUI in a more abstract way by defining reusable composite objects, taking advantage of Python’s language features such as Inheritance, Closures, List Comprehension, Generators, Exception Handling, Arbitrary Precision Integers and others.

\item {} 
Make LittlevGL accessible to a larger audience. No need to know C in order to create a nice GUI on an embedded system.This goes well with \sphinxhref{https://learn.adafruit.com/welcome-to-circuitpython/what-is-circuitpython}{CircuitPython vision}. CircuitPython was designed with education in mind, to make it easier for new or unexperienced users to get started with embedded development.

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\paragraph{So how does it look like?}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:so-how-does-it-look-like}}\begin{quote}

TL;DR:
It’s very much like the C API, but Object Oriented for LittlevGL components.
\end{quote}

Let’s dive right into an example!

\paragraph{How can I use it?}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:how-can-i-use-it}}

\subparagraph{Online Simulator}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:online-simulator}}
If you want to experiment with LittlevGL + Micropython without downloading anything - you can use our online simulator!It’s a fully functional LittlevGL + Micropython that runs entirely in the browser and allows you to edit a python script and run it.

\sphinxhref{https://cdn.statically.io/gh/littlevgl/lv\_micropython/ef943a1ab40b32a8a77059d6e833a440446c51e8/ports/javascript/lvgl\_editor.html?env=dev\&script=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/littlevgl/lv\_binding\_micropython/dev-6.0/examples/chart\_anim\_example.py}{Link to the online simulator}


\subparagraph{PC Simulator}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:pc-simulator}}
Micropython is ported to many platform, one of the is the “unix port”, which allows you to build and run Micropython (+LittlevGL) on a Linux machine. (On a windows machine you might need Virtual Box or WSL or MinGW or Cygwin etc.)

\sphinxhref{https://github.com/littlevgl/lv\_micropython}{More information about building and running the unix port}


\subparagraph{The real thing}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:the-real-thing}}
At the end, the goal is to run it all on an embedded platform.Both Micropython and LittlevGL can be used on many embedded architectures, such as stm32, ESP32 etc.You would also need display and input drivers. We have some example drivers (ESP32+ILI9341, as well as some other examples), but most chances are you would want to create your own input/display drivers for your specific purposes.Drivers can be implemented either in C as Micropython module, or in pure Micropython!

\subsection{移植}
\label{\detokenize{porting/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{porting/index::doc}}

\subsubsection{System overview}
\label{\detokenize{porting/sys:system-overview}}\label{\detokenize{porting/sys::doc}}
\sphinxincludegraphics{{sys}.png}

\sphinxstylestrong{Application}
Your application which creates the GUI and handles the specific tasks.

\sphinxstylestrong{LittlevGL}
The graphics library itself. Your application can communicate with the library to create a GUI. It contains a HAL (Hardware Abstraction Layer) interface to register your display and input device drivers.

\sphinxstylestrong{Driver}
Besides your specific drivers, it contains functions to drive your display, optionally to a GPU and to read the touchpad or buttons.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip


There are \sphinxstylestrong{two typical hardware set-ups} depending on the MCU has an LCD/TFT driver periphery or not. In both cases, a frame buffer will be required to store the current image of the screen.
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{MCU with TFT/LCD driver}
If your MCU has a TFT/LCD driver periphery then you can connect a display directly via RGB interface.
In this case, the frame buffer can be in the internal RAM (if the MCU has enough RAM) or in the external RAM (if the MCU has a memory interface).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{External display controller}
If the MCU doesn’t have TFT/LCD driver interface then an external display controller (E.g. SSD1963, SSD1306, ILI9341) has to be used.
In this case, the MCU can communicate with the display controller via Parallel port, SPI or sometimes I2C.
The frame buffer is usually located in the display controller which saves a lot of RAM for the MCU.

\end{enumerate}


\subsubsection{Set-up a project}
\label{\detokenize{porting/project:set-up-a-project}}\label{\detokenize{porting/project::doc}}

\paragraph{Get the library}
\label{\detokenize{porting/project:get-the-library}}
LittlevGL Graphics Library is available on GitHub: \sphinxurl{https://github.com/littlevgl/lvgl}.

You can clone it or download the latest version of the library from GitHub or you can use the \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/download}{Download} page as well.

The graphics library is the \sphinxstylestrong{lvgl} directory which should be copied into your project.


\paragraph{Config file}
\label{\detokenize{porting/project:config-file}}
There is a configuration header file for LittlevGL called \sphinxstylestrong{lv\_conf.h}. It sets the library’s basic behavior, disables unused modules and features, adjusts the size of memory buffers in compile time, etc.

Copy \sphinxstylestrong{lvgl/lv\_conf\_template.h} next to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{lvgl} directory and rename it to \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. Open the file and change the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#if 0}} at the beginning to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#if 1}} to enable its content.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} can be copied other places as well but then you should add \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CONF\_INCLUDE\_SIMPLE}} define to your compiler options (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-DLV\_CONF\_INCLUDE\_SIMPLE}} for gcc) and set the include path manually.

In the config file comments explain the meaning of the options. Check at least these three configuration options and modify them according to your hardware:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_HOR\_RES\_MAX} Your display’s horizontal resolution

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_VER\_RES\_MAX} Your display’s vertical resolution

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH} 8 for (RG332), 16 for (RGB565) or 32 for (RGB888 and ARGB8888).

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Initialization}
\label{\detokenize{porting/project:initialization}}
In order to use the graphics library you have to initialize it and the other components too. To order of the initialization is:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Call \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_init()}

\item {} 
Initialize your drivers

\item {} 
Register the display and input devices drivers in LittlevGL.  More about {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/display::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Display}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Input device}}}} registration.

\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(x)}} in every \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}} milliseconds in an interrupt to tell the elapsed time. {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/tick::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Learn more}}}}.

\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} periodically in every few milliseconds to handle LittlevGL related tasks. {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Learn more}}}}.

\end{enumerate}


\subsubsection{Display interface}
\label{\detokenize{porting/display:display-interface}}\label{\detokenize{porting/display::doc}}
To set up a display an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_buf\_t}} and an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_t}} variable has to be initialized.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_disp\_buf\_t} contains internal graphics buffer(s).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_disp\_drv\_t} contains callback functions to interact with the display and manipulate drawing related things.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Display buffer}
\label{\detokenize{porting/display:display-buffer}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_buf\_t}} can be initialized like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*A static or global variable to store the buffers*/}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}buf\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{;}
    
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Static or global buffer(s). The second buffer is optional*/}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{buf\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{MY\PYGZus{}DISP\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{buf\PYGZus{}2}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{MY\PYGZus{}DISP\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
    
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Initialize {}`disp\PYGZus{}buf{}` with the buffer(s) */}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}buf\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{buf\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{buf\PYGZus{}2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{MY\PYGZus{}DISP\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

There are there possible configurations regarding the buffer size:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{One buffer} LittlevGL draws the content of the screen into a buffer and sends it to the display.
The buffer can be smaller than the screen. In this case, the larger areas will be redrawn in multiple parts.
If only small areas changes (e.g. button press) then only those areas will be refreshed.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two non-screen-sized buffers} having two buffers LittlevGL can draw into one buffer while the content of the other buffer is sent to display in the background.
DMA or other hardware should be used to transfer the data to the display to let the CPU draw meanwhile.
This way the rendering and refreshing of the display become parallel.
Similarly to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{One buffer} LittlevGL will draw the display’s content in chunks if the buffer is smaller than the area to refresh.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two screen-sized buffers}.
In contrast to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Two non-screen-sized buffers} LittlevGL will always provide the whole screen’s content not only chunks.
This way the driver can simply change the address of the frame buffer to the buffer received from LittlevGL.
Therefore this method works the best when the MCU has an LCD/TFT interface and the frame buffer is just a location in the RAM.

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Display driver}
\label{\detokenize{porting/display:display-driver}}
Once the buffer initialization is ready the display drivers need to be initialized. In the most simple case only the following two fields of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_t}} needs to be set:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{buffer} pointer to an initialized \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_buf\_t}} variable.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{flush\_cb} a callback function to copy a buffer’s content to a specific area of the display.

\end{itemize}

There are some optional data fields:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{hor\_res} horizontal resolution of the display. (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_HOR\_RES\_MAX}} by default from \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ver\_res} vertical resolution of the display. (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_VER\_RES\_MAX}} by default from \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{color\_chroma\_key} a color which will be drawn as transparent on chrome keyed images. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_TRANSP}} by default from \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{user\_data} custom user data for the driver. Its type can be modified in lv\_conf.h.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{anti-aliasing} use anti-aliasing (edge smoothing). \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ANTIALIAS}} by default  from \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{rotated} if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} swap \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hor\_res}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ver\_res}}. LittlevGL draws in the same direction in both cases (in lines from top to bottom) so the driver also needs to be reconfigured to change the display’s fill direction.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{screen\_transp} if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} the screen can have transparent or opaque style. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_SCREEN\_TRANSP}} needs to enabled in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}
To use a GPU the following callbacks can be used:

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{gpu\_fill\_cb} fill an area with colors.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{gpu\_blend\_cb} blend two buffers using opacity.

\end{itemize}

Some other optional callbacks to make easier and more optimal to work with monochrome, gray-scale or other non-standard RGB displays:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{rounder\_cb} round the coordinates of areas to redraw. E.g. a 2x2 px can be converted to 2x8.
It can be used if the display controller can refresh only areas with specific height or width (usually 8 px height with monochrome displays).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{set\_px\_cb} a custom function to write the \sphinxstyleemphasis{display buffer}.
It can be used to store the pixels in a more compact way if the display has a special color format. (e.g. 1 bit monochrome, 2  bit gray-scale etc.)
This way the buffers used in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_buf\_t}} can be smaller to hold only the required number of bits for the given area size.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{monitor\_cb} a callback function tell how many pixels were refreshed in how much time.

\end{itemize}

To set the fields of \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_disp\_drv\_t} variable it needs to be initialized with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_init(\&disp\_drv)}}.
And finally to register a display for LittlevGL \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_register(\&disp\_drv)}} needs to be called.

\subsubsection{Input device interface}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:input-device-interface}}\label{\detokenize{porting/indev::doc}}

\paragraph{Types of input devices}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:types-of-input-devices}}
To set up an input device an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_t}} variable has to be initialized:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Basic initialization*/}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*See below.*/}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}              \PYG{c+cm}{/*See below.*/}
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Register the driver in LittlevGL and save the created input device object*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}indev} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{type} can be
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_POINTER} touchpad or mouse

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_KEYPAD} keyboard or keypad

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_ENCODER} encoder with left, right, push options

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_BUTTON} external buttons pressing the screen

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstylestrong{read\_cb} is a function pointer which will be called periodically to report the current state of an input device.
It can also buffer data and return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{false}} when no more data to be read or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{true}} when the buffer is not empty.

Visit {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Input devices}}}} to learn more about input devices in general.


\subparagraph{Touchpad, mouse or any pointer}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:touchpad-mouse-or-any-pointer}}
Input devices which are able to click points of the screen belong to this category.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}POINTER}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}input\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}input\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{point}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{touchpad\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{;} 
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{point}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{touchpad\PYGZus{}y}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR} \PYG{n}{or} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*No buffering now so no more data read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
Touchpad drivers must return the last X/Y coordinates even when the state is \sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_INDEV\_STATE\_REL}.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

To set a mouse cursor use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_cursor(my\_indev, \&img\_cursor)}}. (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_indev}} is the return value of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_register}})


\subparagraph{Keypad or keyboard}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:keypad-or-keyboard}}
Full keyboards with all the letters or simple keypads with a few navigation buttons belong here.

To use a keyboard/keypad:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Register a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_cb}} function with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_KEYPAD}} type.

\item {} 
Enable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_GROUP}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}

\item {} 
An object group has to be created: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_group\_t * g = lv\_group\_create()}}  and objects have to be added to it with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_group\_add\_obj(g, obj)}}

\item {} 
The created group has to be assigned to an input device: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_group(my\_indev, g)}} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_indev}} is the return value of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_register}})

\item {} 
Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_...}} to navigate among the objects in the group. See \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_core/lv\_group.h}} for the available keys.

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}KEYPAD}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}input\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{keyboard\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{key} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}key}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+cm}{/*Get the last pressed or released key*/}
  
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{key\PYGZus{}pressed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;}
  
  \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*No buffering now so no more data read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subparagraph{Encoder}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:encoder}}
With an encoder you can do 4 things:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Press its button

\item {} 
Long press its button

\item {} 
Turn left

\item {} 
Turn right

\end{enumerate}

In short, the Encoder input devices work like this:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
By turning the encoder you can focus on the next/previous object.

\item {} 
When you press the encoder on a simple object (like a button), it will be clicked.

\item {} 
If you press the encoder on a complex object (like a list, message box, etc.) the object will go to edit mode where by turning the encoder you can navigate inside the object.

\item {} 
To leave edit mode press long the button.

\end{itemize}

To use an \sphinxstyleemphasis{Encoder} (similarly to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keypads}) the objects should be added to groups.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}ENCODER}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}input\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.} 
 
\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{encoder\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{enc\PYGZus{}diff} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{enc\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}new\PYGZus{}moves}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{enc\PYGZus{}pressed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;}
  
  \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*No buffering now so no more data read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subparagraph{Button}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:button}}
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Buttons} mean external “hardware” buttons next to the screen which are assigned to specific coordinates of the screen.
If a button is pressed it will simulate the pressing on the assigned coordinate. (Similarly to a touchpad)

To assign buttons to coordinates use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_button\_points(my\_indev, points\_array)}}.\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{points\_array}} should look like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const lv\_point\_t points\_array{[}{]} =  \{ \{12,30\},\{60,90\}, ...\}}}

\paragraph{Other features}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:other-features}}
Besides \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_cb}} a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{feedback\_cb}} callback can be also specified in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_t}}.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{feedback\_cb}} is called when any type of event is sent by the input devices. (independently from its type). It gives the opportunity to make feedback for the user e.g. to play a sound on \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_CLICK}}.

The default value of the following parameters can be set in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} but the default value can be overwritten in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_t}}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_limit} Number of pixels to slide before actually drag the object

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_throw}  Drag throw slow-down in {[}\%{]}. Greater value means faster slow-down

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{long\_press\_time} Press time to send \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_LONG\_PRESSED}} (in milliseconds)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{long\_press\_rep\_time} Interval of sending \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_LONG\_PRESSED\_REPEAT}} (in milliseconds)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{read\_task} pointer to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task}} which reads the input device. It parameters can be changed by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_...()}} functions

\end{itemize}

Every Input device is associated with a display. By default, a new input device is added to the lastly created or the explicitly selected (using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_set\_default()}}) display.
The associated display is stored and can be changed in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{disp}} field of the driver.

\subsubsection{Tick interface}
\label{\detokenize{porting/tick:tick-interface}}\label{\detokenize{porting/tick::doc}}
The LittlevGL needs a system tick to know the elapsed time for animation and other task.

You need to call the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(tick\_period)}} function periodically and tell the call period in milliseconds. For example, if called in every millisecond: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(1)}}.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc}} should be called in a higher priority routine than\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ lv\_task\_handler()}} (e.g. in an interrupt) to precisely know the elapsed milliseconds even if the execution of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} takes longer time.

With FreeRTOS \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc}} can be called in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{vApplicationTickHook}}.

On Linux based operation system (e.g. on Raspberry) \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc}} can be called in a thread:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nf}{tick\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{args}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
      \PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n}{usleep}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Sleep for 5 millisecond*/}
        \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}tick\PYGZus{}inc}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Tell LittlevGL that 5 milliseconds were elapsed*/}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}} 
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{API}
\label{\detokenize{porting/tick:api}}
Provide access to the system tick with 1 millisecond resolution

\subsubsection{Task Handler}
\label{\detokenize{porting/task-handler:task-handler}}\label{\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}}
To handle the tasks of LittlevGL you need to call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} periodically in one of the followings:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{while(1)} of \sphinxstyleemphasis{main()} function

\item {} 
timer interrupt periodically (low priority then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc()}})

\item {} 
an OS task periodically

\end{itemize}

The timing is not critical but it should be about 5 milliseconds to keep the system responsive.

Example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}delay\PYGZus{}ms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To learn more about task visit the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/task::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Tasks}}}} section.


\subsubsection{Sleep management}
\label{\detokenize{porting/sleep:sleep-management}}\label{\detokenize{porting/sleep::doc}}
The MCU can go to sleep when no user input happens. In this case the main \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{while(1)}} should look like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Normal operation (no sleep) in \PYGZlt{} 1 sec inactivity*/} 
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}inactive\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
	  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}} 
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Sleep after 1 sec inactivity*/}
  \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
	  \PYG{n}{timer\PYGZus{}stop}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Stop the timer where lv\PYGZus{}tick\PYGZus{}inc() is called*/}
	  \PYG{n}{sleep}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}		    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Sleep the MCU*/}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
  \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}delay\PYGZus{}ms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

You should also add these lines to your input device read function if a press happens:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}tick\PYGZus{}inc}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}DISP\PYGZus{}DEF\PYGZus{}REFR\PYGZus{}PERIOD}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Force task execution on wake\PYGZhy{}up*/}
\PYG{n}{timer\PYGZus{}start}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Restart the timer where lv\PYGZus{}tick\PYGZus{}inc() is called*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                     \PYG{c+cm}{/*Call {}`lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler(){}` manually to process the press event*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

In addition to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_get\_inactive\_time()}} you can check \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_count\_running()}} to see if every animations are finished.


\subsubsection{Operating system and interrupts}
\label{\detokenize{porting/os:operating-system-and-interrupts}}\label{\detokenize{porting/os::doc}}
LittlevGL is \sphinxstylestrong{not thread-safe} by default.

However, in the following case it’s valid to call LittlevGL related functions:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
In \sphinxstyleemphasis{events}. Learn more in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.

\item {} 
In \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_tasks}. Learn more in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/task::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Tasks}}}}.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Tasks and threads}
\label{\detokenize{porting/os:tasks-and-threads}}
If you need to use real tasks or threads you need a mutex which should be taken before the call of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} and released after it.
In addition, you have to use to that mutex in other tasks and threads around every LittlevGL (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_...}}) related function call and code.
This way you can use LittlevGL in a real multitasking environment. Just use a mutex to avoid the concurrent calling of LittlevGL functions.


\paragraph{Interrupts}
\label{\detokenize{porting/os:interrupts}}
Try to avoid calling LittlevGL function from an interrupts (except \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc()}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_flush\_ready()}}). But if you really need to do this you have to disable the interrupt which uses LittlevGL functions while \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} is running.
It’s a better approach to set a flag or other value and periodically check it in an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task}}.


\subsubsection{Logging}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:logging}}\label{\detokenize{porting/log::doc}}
LittlevGL has built-in \sphinxstyleemphasis{log} module to inform the user about what is happening in the library.


\paragraph{Log level}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:log-level}}
To enable logging set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_LOG  1}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} and set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL}} to one of the following values:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_TRACE} A lot of logs to give detailed information

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_INFO}  Log important events

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_WARN}  Log if something unwanted happened but didn’t cause a problem

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_ERROR} Only critical issue, when the system may fail

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_NONE}  Do not log anything

\end{itemize}

The events which have higher level than the set log level will be logged too. E.g. if you \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_WARN}}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{errors} will be also logged.


\paragraph{Logging with printf}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:logging-with-printf}}
If your system supports \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{printf}} you just need to enable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LOG\_PRINTF}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} to send the logs with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{printf}}.


\paragraph{Custom log function}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:custom-log-function}}
If you can’t use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{printf}} or want to use a custom function to log you can register a “logger” callback with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_log\_register\_print()}}.

For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}log\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}log\PYGZus{}level\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{level}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{k+kt}{char} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{int} \PYG{n}{line}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{k+kt}{char} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Send the logs via serial port*/}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{level} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LOG\PYGZus{}LEVEL\PYGZus{}ERROR}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{ERROR: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{level} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LOG\PYGZus{}LEVEL\PYGZus{}WARN}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{WARNING: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{level} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LOG\PYGZus{}LEVEL\PYGZus{}INFO}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{INFO: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{level} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LOG\PYGZus{}LEVEL\PYGZus{}TRACE}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{TRACE: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
