\subsubsection{Fonts}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:fonts}}\label{\detokenize{overview/font::doc}}
In LittlevGL fonts are collections of bitmaps and other information required to render the images of the letters (glyph). A font is stored in a \sphinxstylestrong{lv\_font\_t} variable and can be set it in style’s \sphinxstyleemphasis{text.font} field. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{font} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}roboto\PYGZus{}28}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a larger font*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The fonts have a \sphinxstylestrong{bpp (Bit-Per-Pixel)} property. It shows how many bits are used to describe a pixel in the font. The value stored for a pixel determines the pixel’s opacity.
This way with higher \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp} the edges of the letter can be smoother. The possible \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp} values are 1, 2, 4 and 8 (higher value means better quality).

The \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp} also affects the required memory size to store the font. E.g. \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 4} makes the font \textasciitilde{}4 times greater compared to \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 1}.


\paragraph{Unicode support}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:unicode-support}}
LittlevGL supports \sphinxstylestrong{UTF-8} encoded Unicode characters.
You need to configure your editor to save your code/text as UTF-8 (usually this the default) and be sure \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_TXT\_ENC}} is set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_TXT\_ENC\_UTF8}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. (This is the default value)

To test it try

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{label1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If all works well a \(\checkmark\) character should be displayed.


\paragraph{Built-in fonts}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:built-in-fonts}}
There are several built-in fonts in different sizes which can be enabled in lv\_conf.h by \sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_FONT\_…} defines:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_ROBOTO\_12}} 12 px

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_ROBOTO\_16}} 16 px

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_ROBOTO\_22}} 22 px

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_ROBOTO\_28}} 28 px

\end{itemize}

The built-in fonts are \sphinxstylestrong{global variables} with names like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_roboto\_16}} for 16 px hight font. To use them in a style just add a pointer to a font variable like shown above.

The built-in fonts have \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 4}, contains the ASCII characters and uses the \sphinxhref{https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Roboto}{Roboto} font.

In addition to the ASCII rangle, the following symbols are also added to the built-in fonts from the \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com/}{FontAwesome} font.

\sphinxincludegraphics{{symbols}.png}

The symbols can be used as:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or with together with strings:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Apply}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or more symbols together:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}WIFI} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}PLAY}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Add new font}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:add-new-font}}
There are several ways to add a new font to your project:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
The most simple way is to use the \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/font\_conv\_new}{Online font converter}. Just set the parameters, click the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Convert} button, copy the font to your project and use it.

\item {} 
Use the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/littlevgl/lv\_font\_conv}{Offline font converter}. (Requires Node.js to be installed)

\item {} 
If you want to create something like the built-in fonts (Roboto font and symbols) but in different size and/or ranges you can use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{built\_in\_font\_gen.py}} script in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl/scripts/built\_in\_font}} folder.
(It requires Python and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_conv}} to be installed)

\end{enumerate}

To declare the font in a file use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_DECLARE(my\_font\_name)}}.

To make to font globally available add them to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_CUSTOM\_DECLARE}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.


\paragraph{Add new symbols}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:add-new-symbols}}
The built-in symbols are created from \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com/}{FontAwesome} font. To add new symbols from the FontAwesome font do the following steps:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Search symbol on \sphinxurl{https://fontawesome.com}. For example the \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com}{USB symbol}

\item {} 
Open the \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/font\_conv\_new}{Online font converter} add \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/tools/FontAwesome.ttf}{FontAwesome.ttf} and add the Unicode ID of the symbol to the range field. E.g.\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ 0xf287}} for the USB symbol.
More symbols can be enumerated with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{,}}.

\item {} 
Convert the font and copy it to your project.

\item {} 
Convert the Unicode value to UTF8. You can do it e.g.on \sphinxhref{http://www.ltg.ed.ac.uk/\%7Erichard/utf-8.cgi?input=f287\&mode=hex}{this site}. For \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0xf287}} the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Hex UTF-8 bytes} are \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EF 8A 87}}.

\item {} 
Create a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{define}} from the UTF8 values: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#define MY\_USB\_SYMBOL "\textbackslash{}xEF\textbackslash{}x8A\textbackslash{}x87"}}

\item {} 
Use the symbol as the built-in symbols. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text(label, MY\_USB\_SYMBOL)}}

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Add a new font engine}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:add-a-new-font-engine}}
LittlevGL’s font interface is designed to be very flexible.
You don’t need to use LittlevGL’s internal font engine but you can add your own.
For example use \sphinxhref{https://www.freetype.org/}{FreeType} to real-time render glyphs from TTF fonts or use an external flash to store the font’s bitmap and read them when the library need them.

To do this a custom \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_t}} variable needs to be created:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Describe the properties of a font*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}        \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a callback to get info about gylphs*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}bitmap} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}bitmap\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a callback to get bitmap of a glyp*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{line\PYGZus{}height} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{height}\PYG{p}{;}                       \PYG{c+cm}{/*The real line height where any text fits*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{base\PYGZus{}line} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{base\PYGZus{}line}\PYG{p}{;}                      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Base line measured from the top of line\PYGZus{}height*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{something\PYGZus{}required}\PYG{p}{;}                   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Store any implementation specific data here*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{;}                      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Optionally some extra user data*/}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* Get info about glyph of {}`unicode\PYGZus{}letter{}` in {}`font{}` font. }
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Store the result in {}`dsc\PYGZus{}out{}`.}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * The next letter ({}`unicode\PYGZus{}letter\PYGZus{}next{}`) might be used to calculate the width required by this glyph (kerning)}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k}{const} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{font}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{unicode\PYGZus{}letter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{unicode\PYGZus{}letter\PYGZus{}next}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Your code here*/}
  
    \PYG{c+cm}{/* Store the result.}
\PYG{c+cm}{     * For example ... }
\PYG{c+cm}{     */}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{adv\PYGZus{}w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{12}\PYG{p}{;}        \PYG{c+cm}{/*Horizontal space required by the glyph in [px]*/}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{box\PYGZus{}h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Height of the bitmap in [px]*/}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{box\PYGZus{}w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Width of the bitmap in [px]*/}

\subsubsection{Images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:images}}\label{\detokenize{overview/image::doc}}
An image can be a file or variable which stores the image itself and some metadata.


\paragraph{Store images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:store-images}}
You can store images in two places
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
as a variable in the internal memory (RAM or ROM)

\item {} 
as a file

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Variables}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:variables}}
The images stored internally in a variable has \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_dsc\_t}} type with the following fields:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{header}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{cf} Color format. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:color-format}]{\emph{below}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{w} width in pixels (\textless{}= 2048)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{h} height in pixels (\textless{}= 2048)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{always zero} 3 bits which need to be always zero

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{reserved} reserved for future use

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{data} pointer to an array where the image itself is stored

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{data\_size} length of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data}} in bytes

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Files}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:files}}
To deal with files you need to add a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drive} to LittlevGL. In short, a Drive a collection of functions (\sphinxstyleemphasis{open}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{read}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{close}, etc) registered in LittlevGL to make file operation.
You can add an interface to a standard file system (FAT32 on SD card) or you create your own simple file system to read data from an SPI Flash memory.
In every cases, a Drive is just an abstraction to read and/or write data to a memory.
See the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/file-system::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{File system}}}} section to learn more.


\paragraph{Color formats}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:color-formats}}
Various built-in color formats are supported:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR} Simply store the RGB colors

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA} Store the RGB colors but add an Alpha byte too for every pixel

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_CHROMA\_KEYED} Store the RGB color but if a pixel has \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_TRANSP}} (set in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}) color the pixel will be transparent

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_1/2/4/8BIT} Use palette with 2, 4, 16 or 256 colors and store each pixel on 1, 2, 4 or 8 bit

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_1/2/4/8BIT} Store only the Alpha value on 1, 2, 4 or 8 bits. Draw the pixels \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.image.color}} and the set opacity.

\end{itemize}

The bytes of the \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} 32 bit images are stored in the following order
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Blue

\item {} 
Byte 1: Green

\item {} 
Byte 2: Red

\item {} 
Byte 3: Alpha

\end{itemize}

For 16 bit color depth
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Green 3 lower bit, Blue 5 bit

\item {} 
Byte 1: Red 5 bit, Green 3 higher bit

\item {} 
Byte 2: Alpha byte (only with LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA)

\end{itemize}

For 8 bit color depth
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Red 3 bit, Green 3 bit, Blue 2 bit

\item {} 
Byte 2: Alpha byte (only with LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA)

\end{itemize}

You can store images in a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} format to indicate that it’s not a built-in color format and an {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:image-decoder}]{\emph{Image decoder}}} needs to be used to decode the image.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW} A raw image e.g. a PNG or JPG image

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_ALPHA} Indicate that the image has alpha, and an Alpha byte is added for every pixel

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_CHROME\_KEYED} Indicate that the image is chrome keyed as described in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_CHROMA\_KEYED}} above.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Add and use images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:add-and-use-images}}
You can add images to LittlevGL in two ways:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
using the online converter

\item {} 
manually create images

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Online converter}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:online-converter}}
The Online Image Converter is available here: https://littlevgl.com/image-to-c-array

You need to select a \sphinxstyleemphasis{BMP}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{PNG} or \sphinxstyleemphasis{JPG} image, give it a name, select the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:color-format}]{\emph{Color format}}}, select the type (file or variable) and hit the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Convert} button and the result file be download.

In the converter C arrays (variables) the image for all the Color depths (1, 8, 16 or 32) are included and the used image will be selected in compile time based on \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.

IN case of files you need to tell which color format you want
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
RGB332 for 8 bit color depth

\item {} 
RGB565 for 16 bit color depth

\item {} 
RGB565 Swap for 16 bit color depth (two bytes are swapped)

\item {} 
RGB888 for 32 bit color depth

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Manually create an image}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:manually-create-an-image}}
If you calculate an image run-time you can craft an image variable to display it. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{uint8\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+m+mh}{0x00}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x01}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x02}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{always\PYGZus{}zero} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{80}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{80} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}DEPTH} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{cf} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}IMG\PYGZus{}CF\PYGZus{}TRUE\PYGZus{}COLOR}\PYG{p}{,}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the color format*/}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If the color format is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA}} you can set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data\_size}} like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{80 * 60 * LV\_IMG\_PX\_SIZE\_ALPHA\_BYTE}}.

An other option to create image run-time is to use the {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/canvas::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Canvas}}}} object.


\subparagraph{Use images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:use-images}}
The most simple way to use an Image in LittlevGL is to display it with an {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{lv\_img}}}} object:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{icon} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*From variable*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}src}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{icon}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}icon\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*From file*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}src}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{icon}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{S:my\PYGZus{}icon.bin}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If the image was converted with the online converter you should use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_DECLARE(my\_icon\_dsc)}} to declare the icon in the file where you want to use it.


\paragraph{Image decoder}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:image-decoder}}
As you can see in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:color-formats}]{\emph{Color formats}}} section LittlevGL supports several built image formats. However, it doesn’t support for example PNG or JPG out of the box.
To handle non-built-in image formats you need to use external libraries and attach them to LittlevGL via the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Image decoder} interface.

The image decoder consists of 4 images:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{info} get some basic info about the image (width, height and color format)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{open} open the image: either store the decoded image or set it to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} to indicate the image can be read line-by-line

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{read} if \sphinxstyleemphasis{open} didn’t fully open the image this function should give the some decoded data (max 1 line) from a given position.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{close} close the opened image, free the allocated resources.

\end{itemize}

You can add any number of image decoders. When an image needs to be drawn the library will try all the registered image decoder until find one which is able to open the image, i.e. know that format.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TURE\_COLOR\_...}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_INDEXED\_...}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_ALPHA\_...}} formats are known by the built-in decoder.


\subparagraph{Custom image formats}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:custom-image-formats}}
The easiest was to create a custom image is to use the Online image converter and set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw with alpha}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw with chrome keyed}} format. It will just take the every bytes of selected image and write them as image data.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{heafer.cf}} will be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_ALPHA}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_CHROME\_KEYED}} accordingly. You should choose the correct format according to you needs: fully covering image, use alpha channel or use chroma keying.

After decoding, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{raw} formats are considered \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color}. In other words the image decoder should decode the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} images to \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} according to the format described in {[}\#color-formats{]}(Color formats) section.

If you want to create a really custom image you should use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_USER\_ENCODED\_0..7}} color formats. However, the library can draw the images only in \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} format (or \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} but finally it’s supposed to be in \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} format).
So the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_USER\_ENCODED\_...}} formats are not known by the library therefore they should be decoded to one of the known formats from {[}\#color-formats{]}(Color formats) section.
It’s possible to decoded the image to a non-true color format first, for example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_INDEXED\_4BITS}}, and then call the built-in decoder functions to convert it to \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color}.

With \sphinxstyleemphasis{User encoded} formats the color format in the open function (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}header.cf}}) should be changed according to the new format.


\subparagraph{Register an image decoder}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:register-an-image-decoder}}
For example, if you want LittlevGL to “understand” PNG images you need to create a new image decoder and set some functions to open/close the PNG files. It should looks like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Create a new decoder and register functions */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dec} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}info\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dec}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{decoder\PYGZus{}info}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}open\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dec}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{decoder\PYGZus{}open}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dec}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{decoder\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} 


\PYG{c+cm}{/**}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Get info about a PNG image}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param decoder pointer to the decoder where this function belongs}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param src can be file name or pointer to a C array}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param header store the info here}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @return LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK: no error; LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}INV: can\PYGZsq{}t get the info}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n+nf}{decoder\PYGZus{}info}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{src}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}header\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Check whether the type {}`src{}` is known by the decoder*/}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{is\PYGZus{}png}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{src}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}INV}\PYG{p}{;} 

  \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}
  
  \PYG{n}{header}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{cf} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}IMG\PYGZus{}CF\PYGZus{}RAW\PYGZus{}ALPHA}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{header}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{width}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{header}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{height}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Open a PNG image and return the decided image}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param decoder pointer to the decoder where this function belongs}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param dsc pointer to a descriptor which describes this decoding session}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @return LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK: no error; LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}INV: can\PYGZsq{}t get the info}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n+nf}{decoder\PYGZus{}open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}

  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Check whether the type {}`src{}` is known by the decoder*/}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{is\PYGZus{}png}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{src}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}INV}\PYG{p}{;} 
  
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Decode and store the image. If {}`dsc\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}img\PYGZus{}data{}` the {}`read\PYGZus{}line{}` function will be called to get the image data liny\PYGZhy{}by\PYGZhy{}line*/}
  \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{img\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}png\PYGZus{}decoder}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{src}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}

\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param decoder pointer to the decoder the function associated with}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param dsc pointer to decoder descriptor}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param x start x coordinate}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param y start y coordinate}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param len number of pixels to decode}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param buf a buffer to store the decoded pixels}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @return LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK: ok; LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}INV: failed}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n+nf}{decoder\PYGZus{}built\PYGZus{}in\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}line}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}coord\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}
                                                  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}coord\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}coord\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{len}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{uint8\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{buf}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
   \PYG{c+cm}{/*With PNG it\PYGZsq{}s usually not required*/}

   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Copy {}`len{}` pixels from {}`x{}` and {}`y{}` coordinates in True color format to {}`buf{}` */}
  
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Free the allocated resources}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param decoder pointer to the decoder where this function belongs}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * @param dsc pointer to a descriptor which describes this decoding session}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{decoder\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Free all allocated data*/}
  
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Call the built\PYGZhy{}in close function if the built\PYGZhy{}in open/read\PYGZus{}line was used*/}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}built\PYGZus{}in\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{decoder}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

So in summary:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_info}} you should collect some basic information about the image and store it in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{header}}.

\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_open}} you should try to open the image source pointed by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}src}}. It’s type is already in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}src\_type == LV\_IMG\_SRC\_FILE/VARIABLE}}.
If this format/type is not supported by the decoder return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_RES\_INV}}.
However, if you can open the image a pointer to the decoded \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} image should be set in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data}}.
If the format is known but you don’t want decode while image (e.g. no memory for it) set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data = NULL}} to call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_line}} to get the pixels.

\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_close}} you should free all the allocated resources.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_read}} is optional. Decoding the whole image requires extra memory and some computational overhead.
However, if can decode one line of the image without decoding the whole image you can save memory and time.
To indicate that the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line read} function should be used set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data = NULL}} in the open function.

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Manually use an image decoder}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:manually-use-an-image-decoder}}
LittlevGL will use th registered image decoder automatically but you can use them manually too. Create a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_dsc\_t}} variable to describe a the decoding session and call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_open()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_open()}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{res}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}plain}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Do something with {}`dsc\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}img\PYGZus{}data{}`*/}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Image caching}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:image-caching}}
Sometimes it takes a lot of time to open an image.
Continuously decoding a PNG image or loading images from a slow external memory would be effective.
Therefore LittlevGL caches a given number of images. Caching means some images will be left open hence LittlevGl can quickly access them from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data}} instead of decoding the again.


\subparagraph{Cache size}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:cache-size}}
The number of cache entries can be defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CACHE\_DEF\_SIZE}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. The default value is 1 so only the lastly used image will be left open.
The size of cache can be changed in tun-time with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_cache\_set\_size(entry\_num)}}


\subparagraph{Value of images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:value-of-images}}
If you use more images then the cache size LittlevGL can’t cache all of the images. Instead, if a new image needs to be opened but there is no place in the cache the library will close an image.
To decide which image to close LittlevGL measured how much did it take to open the image. Images which more time consuming to open are considered more valuable and LittlevGL tries to cache them longer.
You can manually set the \sphinxstyleemphasis{time to open} value in the decoder open function in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}time\_to\_open = time\_ms}} to give a higher or lower value to the image. (Leave it unchanged to let LittlevGL set it)

Every cache entry has a \sphinxstyleemphasis{“life”} value. Every time an image opening happens through the cache the \sphinxstyleemphasis{life} of all entries are decreased to make them older.
When a cached image is used its \sphinxstyleemphasis{life} is increased by the \sphinxstyleemphasis{time to open} value to make it more alive.

If there is no more space in the cache always the entry with the smallest life will be closed.


\subparagraph{Memory usage}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:memory-usage}}
Note that, the cached image might continuously consume memory. For example, if 3 PNG images are cached, they will consume memory while they are opened.
Therefore it’s the user responsibility to be sure there is enough RAM to cache even the largest images at the same time.


\subparagraph{Clean the cache}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:clean-the-cache}}
Let’s say you have loaded a PNG image into a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_dsc\_t my\_png}} variable and use it in an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img}} object. If the image is already cached and you change \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_png-\textgreater{}data}} you need to notify LittlevGL to cache the image again.
To do this use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_cache\_invalidate\_src(\&my\_png)}}. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} is passed as parameter the whole cache will be cleaned.

\subsubsection{File system}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:file-system}}\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system::doc}}
LittlevGL has File system abstraction module which enables to attache any type of file systems.
The file system are identified by a letter.
For example if the SD card is associated with letter\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'S'}} a file can be reached like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{""S:path/to/file.txt}}.


\paragraph{Add a driver}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:add-a-driver}}
To add a driver an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_drv\_t}} needs to be initialized like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{;} 
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                     \PYG{c+cm}{/*Basic initialization*/}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{letter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+sc}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+sc}{S}\PYG{l+s+sc}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{;}                         \PYG{c+cm}{/*An uppercase letter to identify the drive */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{sizeof}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}object}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Size required to store a file object*/}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{rddir\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{sizeof}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}object}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Size required to store a directory object (used by dir\PYGZus{}open/close/read)*/} 
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{ready\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}ready\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to tell if the drive is ready to use */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{open\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}open\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to open a file */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{close\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to close a file */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to read a file */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{write\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}write\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to write a file */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{seek\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}seek\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to seek in a file (Move cursor) */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{tell\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}tell\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to tell the cursor position  */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{trunc\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}trunc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to delete a file */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{size\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}size\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to tell a file\PYGZsq{}s size */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{rename\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}size\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to rename a file */}


\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dir\PYGZus{}open\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}open\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to open directory to read its content */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dir\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to read a directory\PYGZsq{}s content */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dir\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}       \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to close a directory */}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{free\PYGZus{}space\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}size\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}           \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to tell free space on the drive */}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{;}             \PYG{c+cm}{/*Any custom data if required*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Finally register the drive*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Any of the callbacks can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} to indicate that operation is not supported.

If you use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_open(\&file, "S:/folder/file.txt", LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR)}} LittlevGL checks
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
if there is drive with letter \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'S'}}

\item {} 
checks if it’s \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{open\_cb}} is implemented (not \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}})

\item {} 
calls the set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{open\_cb}} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"folder/file.txt"}} path.

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Usage example}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:usage-example}}
The example below shows how to read from a file:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{res}\PYG{p}{;}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{The mode in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_open}} can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR}} to open for write or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FS\_MODE\_RD \textbar{} LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR}} for both}

This example shows how to read a directory’s content. It’s up to the driver how to mark the directories but in can be a good practice to insert a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'/'}} in front of the directory name.

\PYG{k+kt}{char} \PYG{n}{fn}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{256}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dir}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{fn}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{!}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}FS\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}error\PYGZus{}handling}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*fn is empty if not more files to read*/}
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{strlen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fn}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

    \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZpc{}s}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{fn}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dir}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\paragraph{Use drivers for images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:use-drivers-for-images}}
{\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}} objects can be open from files too (besides variables stored in the flash)

To initialize the for images the following callbacks are required:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
open

\item {} 
close

\item {} 
read

\item {} 
seek

\item {} 
tell

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Animations}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:animations}}\label{\detokenize{overview/animation::doc}}
You can automatically change the value of a variable between a start and an end value using animations.
The animation will happen by the periodical call of an “animator” function with the corresponding value parameter.

The \sphinxstyleemphasis{animator} functions has the following prototype:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{func}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{var}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}var\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

This prototype is compatible with the majority of the \sphinxstyleemphasis{set} function of LittlevGL. For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x(obj, value)}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width(obj, value)}}


\paragraph{Create an animation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:create-an-animation}}
To create an animation an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_t}} variable has to be initialized and configured with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_set\_...()}} functions.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}exec\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the animator function and variable to animate*/} 
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{duration}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{delay}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}values}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{end}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}             \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set start and end values. E.g. 0, 150*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}linear}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set path from {}`lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}...{}` functions or a custom one.*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}ready\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{ready\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}             \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a callback to call then animation is ready. (Optional)*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}playback}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{wait\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+cm}{/*Enable playback of teh animation with {}`wait\PYGZus{}time{}` delay*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}repeat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{wait\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}              \PYG{c+cm}{/*Enable repeat of teh animation with {}`wait\PYGZus{}time{}` delay. Can be compiled with playback*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                             \PYG{c+cm}{/*Start the animation*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

You can apply \sphinxstylestrong{multiple different animations} on the same variable at the same time.
For example animate the x and y coordinates with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_y}}. However, only one animation can exist with a given variable and function pair.
Therefore \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_create()}} will delete the already existing variable-function animations.


\paragraph{Animation path}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:animation-path}}
You can determinate the \sphinxstylestrong{path of animation}. In the most simple case, it is linear which means the current value between \sphinxstyleemphasis{start} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{end}  is changed linearly.
A \sphinxstyleemphasis{path} is a function which calculates the next value to set based on the current state of the animation. Currently, there are the following built-in paths:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_linear} linear animation

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_step} change in one step at the end

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_in} slow at the beginning

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_out} slow at the end

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_in\_out} slow at the beginning and end too

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_overshoot} overshoot the end value

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_bounce} bonce back a little from the end value (like hitting a wall)

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Speed vs time}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:speed-vs-time}}
By default, you can set the animation time. But in some cases, the \sphinxstylestrong{animation speed} is more practical.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_speed\_to\_time(speed, start, end)}} function calculates the required time in milliseconds to reach the end value from a start value with the given speed.
The speed is interpreted in \sphinxstyleemphasis{unit/sec} dimension. For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_speed\_to\_time(20,0,100)}} will give 5000 milliseconds.For example in case of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x}} \sphinxstyleemphasis{unit} is pixels so \sphinxstyleemphasis{20} means \sphinxstyleemphasis{20 px/sec} speed.


\paragraph{Delete animations}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:delete-animations}}
You can \sphinxstylestrong{delete an animation} by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_del(var, func)}} by providing the animated variable and its animator function.

\subsubsection{Tasks}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:tasks}}\label{\detokenize{overview/task::doc}}
LittlevGL has a built-in task system. You can register a functions to call them periodically. The tasks are handled and called in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} which needs to be called periodically in every few milliseconds.
See {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} for more information.

The tasks are non-preemptive which means a task can interrupt an other. Therefore you can call any LittlevGL related function in a task.


\paragraph{Create a task}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:create-a-task}}
To create a new task use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_create(task\_cb, period\_ms, LV\_TASK\_PRIO\_OFF/LOWEST/LOW/MID/HIGH/HIGHEST, user\_data)}}. It will create an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_t *}} variable which can be used later to modify the parameters of the task.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_create\_basic()}} also can be used to create a new task without specifying any parameters.

A task callback should have \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{void (*lv\_task\_cb\_t)(lv\_task\_t *);}} prototype.

For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Use the user\PYGZus{}data*/}
  \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{my\PYGZus{}task called with user data: \PYGZpc{}d}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Do something with LittlevGL*/}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{something\PYGZus{}happened}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n}{something\PYGZus{}happened} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}btn\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{500}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}TASK\PYGZus{}PRIO\PYGZus{}MID}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Ready and Reset}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:ready-and-reset}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_ready(task)}} makes the task run on the next call of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}}.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_reset(task)}} resets the period of a task. It will be called the defined period milliseconds later.


\paragraph{Set parameters}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:set-parameters}}
You can modify some parameters of the tasks later:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_cb(task, new\_cb)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_period(task, new\_period)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_prio(task, new\_priority)}}

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{One-shot tasks}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:one-shot-tasks}}
You can make a task to run only once by calling\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_once(task)}}. The task will be automatically deleted when called for the first time.


\paragraph{Measure idle time}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:measure-idle-time}}
You can get the idle percentage time \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_get\_idle()}}. Note that, it doesn’t measure the idle time of the overall system, only \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}}.
It might be misleading if you use an operating system and call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} in a task.


\paragraph{Asynchronous calls}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:asynchronous-calls}}
In some cases, you can’t do an action immediately. For example, you can’t delete an object right now because something else still uses it or you don’t want to block the execution now.
For these cases, you can use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_async\_call(my\_function, data\_p)}} to make \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_function}} to be called on the next call of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data\_p}} will be passed to function when it’s called.
Note that, only the pointer of the data is saved so you need to ensure that the variable will be “alive” while the function is called. You can use \sphinxstyleemphasis{static}, global or dynamically allocated data.

For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}screen\PYGZus{}clean\PYGZus{}up}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Free some resources related to {}`scr{}`*/}
  
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Finally delete the screen*/}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}del}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Do somethings with the object on the current screen*/}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Delete screen on next call of {}`lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler{}`. So not now.*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}async\PYGZus{}call}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}screen\PYGZus{}clean\PYGZus{}up}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*The screen is still valid so you can do other things with it*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\subsubsection{Drawing}
\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing:drawing}}\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing::doc}}
With LittlevGL you don’t need to draw anything manually. Just create objects (like buttons and labels), move and change them and LittlevGL will refresh and redraw what is required.

However, it might be useful to have a basic understanding of how drawing happens in LittlevGL.

The basic concept is to not draw directly to screen but draw to an internal buffer first and then copy that buffer to screen when the rendering is ready. It has two main advantages:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Avoids flickering} while layers of the UI are drawn. E.g. when drawing a \sphinxstyleemphasis{background + button + text} each “stage” would be visible for a short time.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{It’s faster} because when pixels are redrawn multiple times (e.g. background + button + text) it’s faster to modify a buffer in RAM and finally write one pixel once
than read/write a display directly on each pixel access. (e.g. via a display controller with SPI interface).

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Buffering types}
\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing:buffering-types}}
As you already might learn in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/display::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} section there are 3 types of buffering:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{One buffer} LittlevGL draws the content of the screen into a buffer and sends it to the display. The buffer can be smaller than the screen. In this case, the larger areas will be redrawn in multiple parts. If only small areas changes (e.g. button press) then only those areas will be refreshed.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two non-screen-sized buffers} having two buffers LittlevGL can draw into one buffer while the content of the other buffer is sent to display in the background.
DMA or other hardware should be used to transfer the data to the display to let the CPU draw meanwhile.
This way the rendering and refreshing of the display become parallel. Similarly to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{One buffer} LittlevGL will draw the display’s content in chunks if the buffer is smaller than the area to refresh.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two screen-sized buffers}.
In contrast to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Two non-screen-sized buffers} LittlevGL will always provide the whole screen’s content not only chunks. This way the driver can simply change the address of the frame buffer to the buffer received from LittlevGL.
Therefore this method works the best when the MCU has an LCD/TFT interface and the frame buffer is just a location in the RAM.

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Mechanism of screen refreshing}
\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing:mechanism-of-screen-refreshing}}\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Something happens on the GUI which requires redrawing. E.g. a button has been pressed, a chart has been changed or an animation happened, etc.

\item {} 
LittlevGL saves the changed object’s old and new area into a buffer, called \sphinxstyleemphasis{Invalid area buffer}. For optimization in some cases objects are not added to the buffer:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Hidden objects are not added

\item {} 
Objects completely out of their parent are not added

\item {} 
Areas out of the parent are cropped to the parent’s area

\item {} 
The object on other screens are not added

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
In every \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DISP\_DEF\_REFR\_PERIOD}} (set in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
LittlevGL checks the invalid areas and joins the adjacent or intersecting areas

\item {} 
Takes the first joined area if it’s smaller the \sphinxstyleemphasis{display buffer} then simply draws the areas content to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{display buffer}. If the area doesn’t fit into the buffer draw as many lines as possible to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{display buffer}.

\item {} 
When the area is drawn call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flush\_cb}} from the display driver to refresh the display

\item {} 
If the area was larger than the buffer redraw the remaining parts too.

\item {} 
Do the same with all the joined areas.

\end{itemize}

\end{enumerate}

While an area is redrawn the library searches the most top object which covers the area to redraw and starts to draw from that object.
For example, if a button’s label has changed the library will see that it’s enough to draw the button under the text and it’s not required to draw the background too.

The difference between buffer types regarding the drawing mechanism is the following:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{One buffer} LittlevGL needs to wait for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_flush\_ready()}} (called at the end of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flush\_cb}}) before starting to redraw the next part.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two non-screen-sized buffers} LittlevGL can immediately draw to the second buffer when the first is sent to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flush\_cb}} because the flushing should be done by DMA (or similar hardware) in the background.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two screen-sized buffers} After calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flush\_cb}} the first buffer if being displayed as frame buffer. Its content is copied to the second buffer and all the changes are drawn on top of it.

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{对象类型(小部件)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/index::doc}}

\subsubsection{Base object (lv\_obj)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:base-object-lv-obj}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:overview}}
The Base Object contains the most basic attributes of the objects:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
coordinates

\item {} 
parent object

\item {} 
children

\item {} 
main style

\item {} 
attributes like \sphinxstyleemphasis{Click enable}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drag enable}, etc.

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Coordinates}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:coordinates}}
The object size can be modified with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width(obj, new\_width)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_height(obj, new\_height)}} or in one function with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_size(obj, new\_width, new\_height)}}.

You can set the x and y coordinates relative to the parent with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x(obj, new\_x)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_y(obj, new\_y)}} or in one function with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_pos(obj, new\_x, new\_y)}}.

You can align the object to an other with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align(obj, obj\_ref, LV\_ALIGN\_..., x\_shift, y\_shift)}}.
The second argument is a reference object, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj}} will be aligned to it. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj\_ref = NULL}} then the parent of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj}} will be used.
The third argument is the \sphinxstyleemphasis{type} of alignment. These are the possible options:
\sphinxincludegraphics{{align}.png}

The alignment types build like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ALIGN\_OUT\_TOP\_MID}}.

The last two argument means an x and y shift after the alignment.

For example to align a text below an image: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align(text, image, LV\_ALIGN\_OUT\_BOTTOM\_MID, 0, 10)}}.Or to align a text in the middle of its parent: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align(text, NULL, LV\_ALIGN\_CENTER, 0, 0)}}.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align\_origo}} works similarly to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align}} but it aligns the middle point of the object.
For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align\_origo(btn, image, LV\_ALIGN\_OUT\_BOTTOM\_MID, 0, 0)}} will align the center of the button the bottom of the image.

The parameters of the alignment will be saved in the object if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_OBJ\_REALIGN}} is enabled in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. You can realign the objects manually with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_realign(obj)}}.
It’s equivalent to calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align}} again with the same parameters.

If the alignment happened with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align\_origo}} then it will be used when the object is realigned.

If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_auto\_realign(obj, true)}} is used the object will be realigned automatically if its size changes in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width/height/size()}} functions.

It’s very useful when size animations are applied to the object and the original position needs to be kept.

Note that, the coordinates of screens can’t be changed. Attempting to use these functions on screens will result in undefined behavior.


\subparagraph{Parents and children}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:parents-and-children}}
You can set a new parent for an object with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_parent(obj, new\_parent)}}. To get the current parent use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_parent(obj)}}.

To get the children of an object use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_child(obj, child\_prev)}} (from last to first) or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_child\_back(obj, child\_prev)}} (from first to last).
To get the first child pass \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} as the second parameter and use the return value to iterate through the children. The function will return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} if there is no more children. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{child}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{child} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{child}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Do something with \PYGZdq{}child\PYGZdq{} */}
    \PYG{n}{child} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{child}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_count\_children(obj)}} tells the number of children on an object. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_count\_children\_recursive(obj)}} also tells the number of children but counts children of children recursively.


\subparagraph{Screens}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:screens}}
When you have created a screen like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_create(NULL, NULL)}} you can load it with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load(screen1)}}. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}} function gives you a pointer to the current screen.

If you have more display then it’s important to know that these functions operate on the lastly created or the explicitly selected (with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_set\_default}}) display.

To get the screen of an object use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_screen(obj)}} function.


\subparagraph{Layers}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:layers}}
There are two  automatically generated layers:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
top layer

\item {} 
system layer

\end{itemize}

They are independent of the screens and the same layers will be shown on every screen. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{top layer} is above every object on the screen and  \sphinxstyleemphasis{system layer} is above the \sphinxstyleemphasis{top layer} too.
You can add any pop-up windows to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{top layer} freely. But the \sphinxstyleemphasis{system layer} is restricted to system level things (e.g. mouse cursor will be placed here in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_cursor()}}).

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_layer\_top()}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_layer\_sys()}} functions gives a pointer to the top or system layer.

You can bring an object to the foreground or send it to the background with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_move\_foreground(obj)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_move\_background(obj)}}.

Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/layer::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Layer overview}}}} section to learn more about layers.


\subparagraph{Style}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:style}}
The base object stores the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/style::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Main style}}}} of the object. To set a new style use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_style(obj, \&new\_style)}} function. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} is set as style then the object will inherit its parent’s style.

Note that you shouldn’t use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_style}} is for “non Base objects”. Every object type has its own style set function which should be used for them. E.g. for button \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_style()}}

If you modify a style, which is already used by objects in order to refresh the affected objects you can use either \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_refresh\_style(obj)}} or to notify all object with a given style \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_report\_style\_mod(\&style)}}. If the parameter of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_report\_style\_mod}} is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} all objects will be notified.

Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/style::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Style overview}}}} to learn more about styles.


\subparagraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:events}}
To set an event callback for an object use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_event\_cb(obj, event\_cb)}},

To manually send an event to an object use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_event\_send(obj, LV\_EVENT\_..., data)}}

Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Event overview}}}} to learn more about the events.


\subparagraph{Attributes}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:attributes}}
There are some attributes which can be enabled/disabled by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_...(obj, true/false)}}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{hidden} Hide the object. It will not be drawn and will be considered as if it doesn’t exist., Its children will be hidden too.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{click} Enabled to click the object via input devices. If disabled then object behind this object will be clicked. (E.g. {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Labels}}}} are not clickable by default)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{top} If enabled then when this object or any of its children is clicked then this object comes to the foreground.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag} Enable dragging (moving by an input device)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_dir} Enable dragging only in specific directions. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DRAG\_DIR\_HOR/VER/ALL}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_throw} Enable “throwing” with dragging as if the object would have momentum

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_parent} If enabled then the object’s parent will be moved during dragging. It will look like as if the parent is dragged. Checked recursively, so can propagate to grandparents too.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{parent\_event} Propagate the events to the parents too. Checked recursively, so can propagate to grandparents too.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{opa\_scale\_enable} Enable opacity scaling. See the {[}\#opa-scale{]}(Opa scale) section.

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Opa scale}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:opa-scale}}
If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_opa\_scale\_enable(obj, true)}} is set for an object then the object’s and all of its children’s opacity can be adjusted with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_opa\_scale(obj, LV\_OPA\_...)}}.
The opacities stored in the styles will be scaled down by this factor.

It is very useful to fade in/out an object with some children using an {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/animation::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Animation}}}}.

A little bit of technical background: during the rendering process the object and its parents are checked recursively to find a parent with enabled \sphinxstyleemphasis{Opa scale}.
If an object has found with enabled \sphinxstyleemphasis{Opa scale} then that \sphinxstyleemphasis{Opa scale} will be used by the rendered object too.
Therefore if you want to disable the Opa scaling for an object when the parent has Opa scale just enable Opa scaling for the object and set its value to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_COVER}}. It will overwrite the parent’s settings.


\subparagraph{Protect}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:protect}}
There are some specific actions which happen automatically in the library.
To prevent one or more that kind of actions you can protect the object against them. The following protections exists:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_NONE} No protection

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_POS}  Prevent automatic positioning (e.g.  Layout in {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Containers}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_FOLLOW} Prevent the object be followed (make a “line break”) in automatic ordering (e.g. Layout in {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Containers}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_PARENT} Prevent automatic parent change. (e.g. {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}} moves the children created on the background to the scrollable)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_PRESS\_LOST} Prevent losing press when the press is slid out of the objects. (E.g. a {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} can be released out of it if it was being pressed)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_CLICK\_FOCUS} Prevent automatically focusing the object if it’s in a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Group} and click focus is enabled.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_CHILD\_CHG} Disable the child change signal. Used internally by the library

\end{itemize}

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set/clear\_protect(obj, LV\_PROTECT\_...)}} sets/clears the protection. You can use \sphinxstyleemphasis{‘OR’ed} values of protection types too.


\subparagraph{Groups}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:groups}}
Once an object is added to \sphinxstyleemphasis{group} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_group\_add\_obj(group, obj)}} the object’s current group can be get with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_group(obj)}}.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_is\_focused(obj)}} tells if the object is currently focused in its group or not. If the object is not added to a group \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{false}} will be returned.

Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Input devices overview}}}} to learn more about the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Groups}.


\subparagraph{Extended click area}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:extended-click-area}}
By default, the objects can be clicked only on their coordinates, however this area can be extended with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_ext\_click\_area(obj, left, right, top, bottom)}}.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{left/right/top/bottom}} tells extra size the directions respectively.

This feature needs to enabled in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_EXT\_CLICK\_AREA}}. The possible values are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EXT\_CLICK\_AREA\_FULL} store all 4 coordinates as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_coord\_t}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EXT\_CLICK\_AREA\_TINY} store only horizontal and vertical coordinates (use the greater value of left/right and top/bottom) as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EXT\_CLICK\_AREA\_OFF} Disable this feature

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:styles}}
Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_style(obj, \&style)}} to set a style for a base obejct.

All \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}}  properties are used. The default style for screens is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_scr}}  and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_plain\_color}} for normal objects


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:id1}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/obj:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{Arc (lv\_arc)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/arc:arc-lv-arc}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/arc::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/arc:overview}}
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{Arc} object \sphinxstylestrong{draws an arc} within \sphinxstylestrong{start and end angles} and with a given \sphinxstylestrong{thickness}.


\subparagraph{Angles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/arc:angles}}
To set the angles use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_arc\_set\_angles(arc, start\_angle, end\_angle)}} function. The zero degree is at the bottom of the object and the degrees are increasing in a counter-clockwise direction.
The angles should be in {[}0;360{]} range.


\subparagraph{Notes}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/arc:notes}}
The \sphinxstylestrong{width and height} of the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Arc} should be the \sphinxstylestrong{same}.

Currently, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Arc} object \sphinxstylestrong{does not support anti-aliasing}.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/arc:styles}}
To set the style of an \sphinxstyleemphasis{Arc} object use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_arc\_set\_style(arc, LV\_ARC\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line.rounded} make the endpoints rounded (opacity won’t work properly if set to 1)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line.width} the thickness of the arc

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line.color} the color of the arc.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/arc:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Genreric events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/arc:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{Bar (lv\_bar)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/bar:bar-lv-bar}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/bar::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/bar:overview}}
The Bar objects have got two main parts:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
a \sphinxstylestrong{background} which is the object itself

\item {} 
an \sphinxstylestrong{indicator} which shape is similar to the background but its width/height can be adjusted.

\end{enumerate}

The orientation of the bar can be vertical or horizontal according to the width/height ratio. Logically on horizontal bars, the indicator’s width, on vertical bars the indicator’s height can be changed.


\subparagraph{Value and range}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/bar:value-and-range}}
A new value can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_value(bar, new\_value, LV\_ANIM\_ON/OFF)}}.
The value is interpreted in a range (minimum and maximum values) which can be modified with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_range(bar, min, max)}}.
The default range is 1..100.

The new value in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_value}} can be set with our without an animation depending on the last parameter (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ANIM\_ON/OFF}}).
The time of the animation can be adjusted by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_anim\_time(bar, 100)}}. The time is in milliseconds unit.


\subparagraph{Symmetrical}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/bar:symmetrical}}
The bar can be drawn symmetrical to zero (drawn from zero left to right) if it’s enabled with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_sym(bar, true)}}


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/bar:styles}}
To set the style of an \sphinxstyleemphasis{Bar} object use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_style(arc, LV\_BAR\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BAR\_STYLE\_BG} is an {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/obj::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Base object}}}} therefore it uses its style elements. Its default style is: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_pretty}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BAR\_STYLE\_INDIC} is similar to the background. It uses the \sphinxstyleemphasis{left}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{right}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{top} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{bottom} paddings to keeps some space form the edges of the background. Its default style is: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_pretty\_color}}.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/bar:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/bar:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.
