\subsubsection{Button (lv\_btn)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:button-lv-btn}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:overview}}
Buttons are simple rectangle-like objects, but they change their style and state when they are pressed or released.


\subparagraph{States}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:states}}
Buttons can be in one of the 5 possible states:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_REL} Released state

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_PR} Pressed state

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_TGL\_REL} Toggled released state

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_TGL\_PR} Toggled pressed state

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_INA} Inactive state

\end{itemize}

The state from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{...\_REL}} to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{...\_PR}} will be changed automatically when the button is pressed and back when released.

You can set the button’s state manually with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_state(btn, LV\_BTN\_STATE\_TGL\_REL)}}.


\subparagraph{Toggle}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:toggle}}
You can configure the buttons as \sphinxstyleemphasis{toggle button} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_toggle(btn, true)}}. In this case on release, the button goes to \sphinxstyleemphasis{toggled released} state.


\subparagraph{Layout and Fit}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:layout-and-fit}}
Similarly to {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Containers}}}} buttons also have layout and fit attributes.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_layout(btn, LV\_LAYOUT\_...) }}set a layout. The default is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LAYOUT\_CENTER}}.
So if you add a label, then it will be automatically aligned to the middle and can’t be moved with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_pos()}}.
You can disable the layout with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_layout(btn, LV\_LAYOUT\_OFF)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_fit/fit2/fit4(btn, LV\_FIT\_..)}} enables to set the button width and/or height automatically according to the children, parent, and fit type.

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Ink effect}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:ink-effect}}
You can enable a special animation on buttons: when a button is pressed, the pressed state will be drawn in a growing circle starting from the point of pressing. It’s like an ink droplet in the water.
When the button is released, the released state will be reverted by fading. It’s like the ink is fully mixed with a lot of water and become no visible in it.

To control this animation use the following functions:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_ink\_in\_time(btn, time\_ms)}} time of circle growing

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_ink\_wait\_time(btn, time\_ms)}} minim time to keep the fully covering (pressed) state

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_ink\_out\_time(btn, time\_ms)}} time fade back to releases state

\end{itemize}

This feature needs to be enabled with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTN\_INK\_EFFECT  1}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:styles}}
A button can have 5 independent styles for the 5 state. You can set them via: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_style(btn, LV\_BTN\_STYLE\_..., \&style)}}. The styles use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STYLE\_REL} style of the released state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_rel}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STYLE\_PR} style of the pressed state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_pr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STYLE\_TGL\_REL} style of the toggled released state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_rel}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STYLE\_TGL\_PR} style of the toggled pressed state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_pr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STYLE\_INA} style of the inactive state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_ina}}

\end{itemize}

When you create a label on a button, it’s a good practice to set the button’s \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}} properties too. Because labels have \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style = NULL}} by default, they inherit the parent’s (button) style.
Hence you don’t need to create a new style for the label.


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} sent when the button is toggled.

\end{itemize}

Note that the generic input device-related events (like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED}}) are sent in the inactive state too. You need to check the state with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_get\_state(btn)}} to ignore the events from inactive buttons.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btn:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP} Go to toggled state if toggling is enabled

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/DOWN} Go to non-toggled state if toggling is  enabled

\end{itemize}

Note that, as usual, the state of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} is translated to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED/PRESSING/RELEASED}} etc.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{Button matrix (lv\_btnm)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:button-matrix-lv-btnm}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:overview}}
The Button Matrix objects can display \sphinxstylestrong{multiple buttons} in rows and columns.


\subparagraph{Button’s text}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:button-s-text}}
There is a text on each button. To specify them a descriptor string array, called \sphinxstyleemphasis{map}, needs to be used.
The map can be set with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_set\_map(btnm, my\_map)}}.
The declaration of a map should look like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char * map{[}{]} = \{"btn1", "btn2", "btn3", ""\}}}.
Note that \sphinxstylestrong{the last element has to be an empty string}!

Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"\textbackslash{}n"}} in the map  to make \sphinxstylestrong{line break}. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{"btn1", "btn2", "\textbackslash{}n", "btn3", ""\}}}. The button’s width is recalculated in every line to will the whole line.


\subparagraph{Control buttons}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:control-buttons}}
The \sphinxstylestrong{buttons width} can be set relative to the other button in the same line with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_set\_btn\_width(btnm, btn\_id, width)}}
E.g. in a line with two buttons: \sphinxstyleemphasis{btnA, width = 1} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{btnB, width = 2}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{btnA} will have 33 \% width adnd \sphinxstyleemphasis{btnB} will have 66 \% width.

In addition to width each button can be customized with the following parameters:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_HIDDEN} make a button hidden

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_NO\_REPEAT} disable repeating when the button is long pressed

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_INACTIVE} make a button inactive

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_TGL\_ENABLE} enable toggling of a button

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_TGL\_STATE} set the toggle state

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_CLICK\_TRIG} if 0 the button will react on press, if 1 will react on release

\end{itemize}

The set or clear a button’s control attribute use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_set\_btn\_ctrl(btnm, btn\_id, LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_clear\_btn\_ctrl(btnm, btn\_id, LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...)}} respectively. More \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...}} values can be \sphinxstyleemphasis{Or}ed

The set/clear the same control attribute for all buttons of a button matrix use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_set\_btn\_ctrl\_all(btnm, btn\_id, LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_clear\_btn\_ctrl\_all(btnm, btn\_id, LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...)}}.

The set a control map for a button matrix (similarly to the map for the text) use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_set\_ctrl\_map(btnm, ctrl\_map)}}.
An element of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ctrl\_map}} should look like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ctrl\_map{[}0{]} = width \textbar{} LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_NO\_REPEAT \textbar{}  LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_TGL\_ENABLE}}. The number of elements should be equal to the number of buttons (excluding newlines characters).


\subparagraph{One toggle}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:one-toggle}}
The “One toggle” feature can be enabled with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_set\_one\_toggle(btnm, true)}} to allow only one toggled button at once.


\subparagraph{Recolor}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:recolor}}
The \sphinxstylestrong{texts} on the button can be \sphinxstylestrong{recolored} similarly to the recolor feature for {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Label}}}} object. To enabel it use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_set\_recolor(btnm, true)}}. After that a button with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#FF0000 Red\#}} text will be red.


\subparagraph{Notes}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:notes}}
The Button matrix object is very light weighted because the buttons are not created just virtually drawn on the fly.
This way 1 button use only 8 extra bytes instead of the \textasciitilde{}100-150 byte size of a normal {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} object.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:styles}}
The Button matrix works with 6 styles: a background and 5 button styles for each state. You can set the styles with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnm\_set\_style(btn, LV\_BTNM\_STYLE\_..., \&style)}}.
The background and the buttons use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties. The labels use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}} properties of the button styles.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_STYLE\_BG} Background style. Uses all \sphinxstyleemphasis{style.body} properties including \sphinxstyleemphasis{padding} Default: \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_style\_pretty}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_STYLE\_BTN\_REL} style of the released  buttons. Default: \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_style\_btn\_rel}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_STYLE\_BTN\_PR} style of the pressed buttons. Default: \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_style\_btn\_pr}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_STYLE\_BTN\_TGL\_REL} style of the toggled released  buttons. Default: \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_rel}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_STYLE\_BTN\_TGL\_PR} style of the toggled pressed  buttons. Default: \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_pr}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNM\_STYLE\_BTN\_INA} style of the inactive  buttons. Default: \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_style\_btn\_ina}

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/events.html\#generic-event}{Genreric events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the button matrices:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} sent when the button is pressed/released or repeated after long press. The event data is set to ID of the pressed/released button.

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.

\#\#Keys

The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP/LEFT/RIGHT} To navigate among the buttons to select one

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ENTER} To press/release the selected button

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\label{\detokenize{object-types/btnm:example}}

\subsubsection{Calendar (lv\_calendar)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:calendar-lv-calendar}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:overview}}
The Calendar object is a classic calendar which can:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
highlight the current day and week

\item {} 
highlight any user-defined dates

\item {} 
display the name of the days

\item {} 
go the next/previous month by button click

\item {} 
highlight the clicked day

\end{itemize}

The set and get dates in the calendar the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_date\_t}} type is used which is a structure with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{year}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{month}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{day}} fields.


\subparagraph{Current date}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:current-date}}
To set the current date (today) use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_today\_date(calendar, \&today\_date)}} function.


\subparagraph{Shown date}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:shown-date}}
To set the shown date use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_shown\_date(calendar, \&shown\_date)}};


\subparagraph{Highlighted days}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:highlighted-days}}
The list of highlighted dates should be stored in a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_date\_t}} array a loaded by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_highlighted\_dates(calendar, \&highlighted\_dates)}}.Only the arrays pointer will be saved so the array should be a static or global variable.


\subparagraph{Name of the days}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:name-of-the-days}}
The name of the days can be adjusted with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_day\_names(calendar, day\_names)}} where \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{day\_names}} looks like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char * day\_names{[}7{]} = \{"Su", "Mo", ...\};}}


\subparagraph{Name of the months}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:name-of-the-months}}
Similarly to day names the name of the month can be set with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_month\_names(calendar, month\_names\_array)}}.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:styles}}
You can set the styles with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_style(btn, LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_..., \&style)}}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_BG} Style of the background using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{body}} properties and the style of the date numbers using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text}} properties. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{body.padding.left/rigth/bottom}} padding will be added on the edges. around the date numbers.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_HEADER} Style of the header where the current year and month is displayed. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{body}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text}} properties are used.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_HEADER\_PR} Pressed header style, used when the next/prev. month button is being pressed. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text}} properties are used by the arrows.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_DAY\_NAMES} Style of the day names. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text}} properties are used by the day texts and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{body.padding.top}} determines the space above the day names.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_HIGHLIGHTED\_DAYS} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text}} properties are used to adjust the style of the highlights days

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_INACTIVE\_DAYS} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text}} properties are used to adjust the style of the visible days of previous/next month.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_WEEK\_BOX} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{body}} properties are used to set the style of the week box

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CALENDAR\_STYLE\_TODAY\_BOX} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{body}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text}} properties are used to set the style of the today box

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the calendars:
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} is sent when the current month has changed.

In \sphinxstyleemphasis{Input device related} events \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_get\_pressed\_date(calendar)}} tells which day is currently being pressed or return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} if no date is pressed.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/calendar:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{Canvas (lv\_canvas)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:canvas-lv-canvas}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:overview}}
A Canvas is like an {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}} where the user can draw anything.


\subparagraph{Buffer}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:buffer}}
The Canvas needs a buffer which stores the drawn image.
To assign a buffer to a Canvas use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_set\_buffer(canvas, buffer, width, height, LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA)}}.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} is a static buffer (not just a local variable) to hold the image of the canvas.
For example
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{static lv\_color\_t buffer{[}LV\_CANVAS\_BUF\_SIZE\_TRUE\_COLOR(width, height){]}}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CANVAS\_BUF\_SIZE\_...}} macros help to determine the size of the buffer with different color formats.


\subparagraph{Palette}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:palette}}
For \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_...}} color formats a palette needs to be initialized with  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_set\_palette(canvas, 3, LV\_COLOR\_RED)}}. It sets pixels with \sphinxstyleemphasis{index=3} to red.


\subparagraph{Drawing}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:drawing}}
To set a pixel on the canvas use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_set\_px(canvas, x, y, LV\_COLOR\_RED)}}.
With \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_...}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_...}} the index of the color or the alpha value needs to be passed as color. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t c; c.full = 3;}}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_fill\_bg(canvas, LV\_COLOR\_BLUE)}} fills the whole canvas to blue.

An array of pixels can be copied to the canvas with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_copy\_buf(canvas, buffer\_to\_copy, x, y, width, height)}}. The color format of the buffer and the canvas need to match.

To draw something to the canvas use
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_rect(canvas, x, y, width, heigth, \&style)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_text(canvas, x, y, max\_width, \&style, txt, LV\_LABEL\_ALIGN\_LEFT/CENTER/RIGTH)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_img(canvas, x, y, \&img\_src, \&style)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_line(canvas, point\_array, point\_cnt, \&style)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_polygon(canvas, points\_array, point\_cnt, \&style)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_arc(canvas, x, y, radius, start\_angle, end\_angle, \&style)}}

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Rotate}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:rotate}}
A rotated image can be added to canvas with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_rotate(canvas, \&imd\_dsc, angle, x, y, pivot\_x, pivot\_y)}}.
It will rotate the image shown by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{img\_dsc}} around the given pivot and stores it on the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{y}} coordinates of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{canvas}}.
Instead of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{img\_dsc}} and the buffer of an other canvas also can be used by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_get\_img(canvas)}}.

Note that a canvas can’t be rotated on itself.  You need a source and destination canvas or image.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:styles}}
You can set the styles with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_set\_style(btn, LV\_CANVAS\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.image.color}} is used to tell the base color with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_...}} color format.


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/canvas:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{Check box (lv\_cb)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb:check-box-lv-cb}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb:overview}}
The Check Box objects are built from a {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} background which contains an also Button \sphinxstyleemphasis{bullet} and a {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Label}}}} to realize a classical check box.


\subparagraph{Text}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb:text}}
The text can be modified by the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cb\_set\_text(cb, "New text")}} function. It will dynamically allocate the text.

To set a static text use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cb\_set\_static\_text(cb, txt)}}. This way only a pointer of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{txt}} will be stored it shouldn’t be deallocated while the checkbox exists.


\subparagraph{Check/Uncheck}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb:check-uncheck}}
You can manually check / un-check the Check box  via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cb\_set\_checked(cb, true/false)}}.


\subparagraph{Inactive}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb:inactive}}
To make the Check box inactive use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cb\_set\_inactive(cb, true)}}.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb:styles}}
The Check box styles can be modified with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cb\_set\_style(cb, LV\_CB\_STYLE\_..., \&style)}}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CB\_STYLE\_BG} Background style. Uses all \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties. The label’s style comes from  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}}. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_transp}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CB\_STYLE\_BOX\_REL} Style of the released box. Uses the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_rel}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CB\_STYLE\_BOX\_PR} Style of the pressed box. Uses the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_pr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CB\_STYLE\_BOX\_TGL\_REL} Style of the checked released box. Uses the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_rel}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CB\_STYLE\_BOX\_TGL\_PR} Style of the checked released box. Uses the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_pr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CB\_STYLE\_BOX\_INA} Style of the inactive box. Uses the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_ina}}

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the Check boxes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} sent when the Check box is toggled.

\end{itemize}

Note that the generic input device related events (like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED}}) are sent in the inactive state too. You need to check the state with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cb\_is\_inactive(cb)}} to ignore the events from inactive Check boxes.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cb:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP} Go to toggled state if toggling is enabled

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/DOWN} Go to non-toggled state if toggling is  enabled

\end{itemize}

Note that, as usual, the state of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} is translated to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED/PRESSING/RELEASED}} etc.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{Chart (lv\_chart)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:chart-lv-chart}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:overview}}
Charts have a rectangle-like background with horizontal and vertical division lines and data series drawn from lines, points colums or areas.


\subparagraph{Data series}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:data-series}}
You can add any number of series to the charts by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_add\_series(chart, color)}}.
It allocates data for a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_series\_t}} structure which contains the chosen \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{color}} and an array for the data points.


\subparagraph{Series’ type}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:series-type}}
The following \sphinxstylestrong{data display types} exists:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_NONE} do not display any data. It can be used to hide a series.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_LINE} draw lines between the points

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_COL} Draw columns

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_POINT} Draw points

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_AREA} Draw areas (fill the area below the lines)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_VERTICAL\_LINE} Draw only vertical lines to connect the points. Useful if the chart width is equal to the number of points.

\end{itemize}

You can specify the display type with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_type(chart, LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_...)}}. The types can be ‘OR’ed (like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_LINE \textbar{} LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_POINT}}).


\subparagraph{Modify the data}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:modify-the-data}}
You have several options to set the data of series:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Set the values manually in the array like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ser1-\textgreater{}points{[}3{]} = 7}} and refresh the chart with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_refresh(chart)}}.

\item {} 
Use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_next(chart, ser, value)}}

\item {} 
Initialize all points to a given value with: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_init\_points(chart, ser, value)}}.

\item {} 
Set all points from an array with: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_points(chart, ser, value\_array)}}.

\end{enumerate}

Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHART\_POINT\_DEF}} as value to make the library to not draw that point, column, or line segment.


\subparagraph{Update modes}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:update-modes}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_next}} can behave in two way depending on \sphinxstyleemphasis{update mode}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_UPDATE\_MODE\_SHIFT} Shift old data to the left and add the new one o the right

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_UPDATE\_MODE\_CIRCULAR} Add the new data in a circular way. (Like an ECG diagram)

\end{itemize}

To update mode can be changed with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_update\_mode(chart, LV\_CHART\_UPDATE\_MODE\_...)}}.


\subparagraph{Number of points}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:number-of-points}}
The number of points in the series can be modified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_point\_count(chart, point\_num)}}. The default value is 10.


\subparagraph{Vertical range}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:vertical-range}}
You can specify a the min. and max. values in y directions with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_range(chart, y\_min, y\_max)}}. The value of the points will be scaled proportionally. The default range is: 0..100.


\subparagraph{Division lines}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:division-lines}}
The number of horizontal and vertical division lines can be modified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_div\_line\_count(chart, hdiv\_num, vdiv\_num)}}. The default settings are 3 horizontal and 5 vertical division lines.


\subparagraph{Series’ appearance}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:series-appearance}}
To set the \sphinxstylestrong{line width} and \sphinxstylestrong{point radius} of the series use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_series\_width(chart, size)}} function. The default value is: 2.

The \sphinxstylestrong{opacity of the data lines} can be specified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_series\_opa(chart, opa)}}. The default value is: OPA\_COVER.

You can apply a \sphinxstylestrong{dark color fade} on the bottom of columns and points by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_series\_darking(chart, effect)}} function. The default dark level is OPA\_50.


\subparagraph{Tick marks and labels}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:tick-marks-and-labels}}
Ticks and texts to ticks can be added.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_x\_tick\_text(chart, list\_of\_values, num\_tick\_marks, LV\_CHART\_AXIS\_...)}} set the ticks and texts on x axis.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list\_of\_values}} is a string with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'\textbackslash{}n'}} terminated text (expect the last) with text for the ticks. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char * list\_of\_values = "first\textbackslash{}nseco\textbackslash{}nthird"}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list\_of\_values}} can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}}.
If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list\_of\_values}} is set then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{num\_tick\_marks}} tells the number of ticks between two labels.  If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list\_of\_values}} is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} then it specifies the total number of ticks.

Where text are added \sphinxstyleemphasis{major tick lines} are drawn, ot the other places \sphinxstyleemphasis{minor tick lines}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_x\_tick\_length(chart, major\_tick\_len, minor\_tick\_len)}} sets the length of tick lines on the x axis.

The same functions exists for the y axis too: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_y\_tick\_text}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_y\_tick\_length}}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_margin(chart, 20)}} needs to be used to add some extra space around the chart for the ticks and texts.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:styles}}
You can set the styles with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_style(btn, LV\_CHART\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{style.body} properties set the background’s appearance

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{style.line} properties set the division lines’ appearance

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{style.text} properties set the axis labels’ appearance

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\label{\detokenize{object-types/chart:example}}

\subsubsection{Container (lv\_cont)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cont:container-lv-cont}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/cont::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cont:overview}}
The containers are \sphinxstylestrong{rectangle-like object} with some special features.


\subparagraph{Layout}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cont:layout}}
You can apply a layout on the containers to automatically order their children. The layout spacing comes from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body.padding. ...}} properties. The possible layout options:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_OFF} Do not align the children

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_CENTER} Align children to the center in column and keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between them

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_COL\_}: Align children in a left justified column. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left}} space on the left, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pad.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_COL\_M} Align children in centered column. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_COL\_R} Align children in a right justified column. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.right}} space on the right, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_ROW\_T} Align children in a top justified row. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left}} space on the left, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_ROW\_M} Align children in centered row. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left}} space on the left and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_ROW\_B} Align children in a bottom justified row. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left}} space on the left, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.bottom}} space on the bottom and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_PRETTY} Put as may objects as possible in a row (with at least \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left/right}} space on the sides). Divide the space in each line equally between the children.
Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pad.inner}} space between the lines.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_GRID} Similar to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LAYOUT\_PRETTY}} but not divide horizontal space equally just let \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left/right}} on the edges and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space betweenthe elemnts.

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Auto fit}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/cont:auto-fit}}
Container have an auto fit features whcih can automaticall change the size of the Container accoring to its children and/or parent. The following optionas are exist:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_FIT\_NONE} Do not change the size automatically

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_FIT\_TIGHT} Set the size to involve all children by keeping \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top/bottom/left/right}} space on the edges.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_FIT\_FLOOD} Set the size to the parents size by keeping \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top/bottom/left/right}} (from the parent’s style) space.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_FIT\_FILL} Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FIT\_FLOOD}} while smaller than the parent and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FIT\_TIGHT}} when larger.

\end{itemize}

To set the auto fit use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cont\_set\_fit(cont, LV\_FIT\_...)}}. It will set the same auto fit in every directions.
To use different auto fit horizontally and vertically use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cont\_set\_fit2(cont, hor\_fit\_type, ver\_fit\_type)}}.
To use different auto fit in all 4 directions use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cont\_set\_fit4(cont, left\_fit\_type, right\_fit\_type, top\_fit\_type, bottom\_fit\_type)}}.

\subsubsection{Drop down list (lv\_ddlist)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:drop-down-list-lv-ddlist}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:overview}}
Drop Down Lists allow you to simply select one option from more. The Drop Down List is closed by default an show the currently selected text. If you click on it the list opens and all the options are shown.


\subparagraph{Set options}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:set-options}}
The options are passed to the Drop Down List as a string with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_options(ddlist, options)}}. The options should be separated by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}n}}. For example: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"First\textbackslash{}nSecond\textbackslash{}nThird"}}.

You can select an option manually with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_selected(ddlist, id)}}, where \sphinxstyleemphasis{id} is the index of an option.


\subparagraph{Get selected option}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:get-selected-option}}
The get the currently selected option use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_get\_selected(ddlist)}} it will return the \sphinxstyleemphasis{index} of the selected option.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_get\_selected\_str(ddlist, buf, buf\_size)}} copies the name of the selected option to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buf}}.


\subparagraph{Align the options}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:align-the-options}}
To align the label horizontally use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_align(ddlist, LV\_LABEL\_ALIGN\_LEFT/CENTER/RIGHT)}}.


\subparagraph{Height and width}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:height-and-width}}
By default, the list’s height is adjusted automatically to show all options. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_fix\_height(ddlist, height)}} sets a fixed height for the opened list. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0}} means to use auto height.

The width is also adjusted automatically. To prevent this apply \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_fix\_width(ddlist, width)}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0}} means to use auto width.


\subparagraph{Scrollbars}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:scrollbars}}
Similarly to {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}} with fix height the Drop Down List supports various scrollbar display modes. It can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_sb\_mode(ddlist, LV\_SB\_MODE\_...)}}.


\subparagraph{Animation time}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:animation-time}}
The Drop Down List open/close animation time is adjusted by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_anim\_time(ddlist, anim\_time)}}. Zero animation time means no animation.


\subparagraph{Decoration arrow}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:decoration-arrow}}
A down arrow can be added to the left side of the Drop down list with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_draw\_arrow(ddlist, true)}}.


\subparagraph{Stay open}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:stay-open}}
You can force the Drop down list to \sphinxstylestrong{stay opened} when an option is selected with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_stay\_open(ddlist, true)}}.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:styles}}
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_ddlist\_set\_style(ddlist, LV\_DDLIST\_STYLE\_..., \&style)}} set the styles of a Drop Down List.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_DDLIST\_STYLE\_BG} Style of the background. All \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties are used. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}} is used for the option’s label. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_pretty}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_DDLIST\_STYLE\_SEL} Style of the selected option.  The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties are used. The selected option will be recolored with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text.color}}. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_plain\_color}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_DDLIST\_STYLE\_SB} Style of the scrollbar. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties are used. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_plain\_color}}

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the Drop down lists:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} sent when the a new option is selected

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/ddlist:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/DOWN} Select the next option

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/UP} Select the previous option

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LY\_KEY\_ENTER} Apply the selected option (Send \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED}} event and close the Drop down list)

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Gauge (lv\_gauge)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:gauge-lv-gauge}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:overview}}
The gauge is a meter with scale labels and needles.


\subparagraph{Scale}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:scale}}
You can use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_scale(gauge, angle, line\_num, label\_cnt)}} function to adjust the scale angle and the number of the scale lines and labels.
The default settings are 220 degrees, 6 scale labels, and 21 lines.


\subparagraph{Needles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:needles}}
The gauge can show more than one needle.
Use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_needle\_count(gauge, needle\_num, color\_array)}} function to set the number of needles and an array with colors for each needle. The array must be static or global variable because only its pointer is stored.

You can use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_value(gauge, needle\_id, value)}} to set the value of a needle.


\subparagraph{Range}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:range}}
The range of the gauge can be specified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_range(gauge, min, max)}}. The default range is 0..100.


\subparagraph{Critical value}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:critical-value}}
To set a critical value use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_critical\_value(gauge, value)}}. The scale color will be changed to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{line.color}} after this value. (default: 80)


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:styles}}
The gauge uses one style which can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_style(gauge, LV\_GAUGE\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}. The gauge’s properties are derived from the following style attributes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{body.main\_color} line’s color at the beginning of the scale

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{body.grad\_color} line’s color at the end of the scale (gradient with main color)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{body.padding.left} line length

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{body.padding.inner} label distance from the scale lines

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{body.radius} radius of needle origin circle

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line.width} line width

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line.color} line’s color after the critical value

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{text.font/color/letter\_space} label attributes

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\paragraph{Example}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/gauge:example}}

\subsubsection{Image (lv\_img)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:image-lv-img}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/img::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:overview}}
The Images are the basic object to display images.


\subparagraph{Image source}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:image-source}}
To provide maximum flexibility the source of the image can be:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
a variable in the code (a C array with the pixels)

\item {} 
a file stored externally (like on an SD card)

\item {} 
a text with {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/font::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Symbols}}}}

\end{itemize}

To set the source of an image use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img, src)}}

To generate a \sphinxstylestrong{pixel array} from a PNG, JPG or BMP image use the \sphinxhref{https://littlevgl.com/image-to-c-array}{Online image converter tool} and set the converted image with its pointer: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img1, \&converted\_img\_var);}}
To make the variable visible in the C file you need to declare it with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_DECLARE(converted\_img\_var)}}

To use \sphinxstylestrong{external files} you also need to convert the image files using the online converter tool but now you should select the binary Output format.
You also need to use LittlevGL’s file system module and register a driver with some functions for the basic file operation. Got to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/file-system::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{File system}}}} to learn more.
To set an image source form a file use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img, "S:folder1/my\_img.bin")}}

You can set a \sphinxstylestrong{symbol}  similarly to {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Labels}}}}. In this case, the image will be rendered as text according to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{font} specified in the style.  It enables to use of light weighted mono-color
“letters” instead of real images. You can set symbol like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img1, LV\_SYMBOL\_OK)}}


\subparagraph{Label as an image}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:label-as-an-image}}
Images and labels are sometimes for the same thing. E.g.to describe what a button does. Therefore Images and Labels are somewhat interchangeable.
To handle these images can even display texts by using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_SYMBOL\_DUMMY}} as the prefix of the text. For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img, LV\_SYMBOL\_DUMMY "Some text")}}


\subparagraph{Transparency}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:transparency}}
The internal (variable) and external images support 2 transparency handling methods:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Chrome keying} pixels with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_TRANSP}} (\sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}) color will be transparent

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Alpha byte} An alpha byte is added to every pixel

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Palette and Alpha index}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:palette-and-alpha-index}}
Besides \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} (RGB) color format the following formats are also supported:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Indexed} image has a palette

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Alpha indexed} only alpha values are stored

\end{itemize}

These options can be selected in the font converter. To learn more about the color formats read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Images}}}} section.


\subparagraph{Recolor}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:recolor}}
The images can be re-colored in run-time to any color according to the brightness of the pixels.
It is very useful to show different states (selected, inactive, pressed etc) of an image without storing more versions of the same image.
This feature can be enabled in the style by setting \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{img.intense}} between \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP}} (no recolor, value: 0) and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_COVER}} (full recolor, value: 255).
The default value is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP}} so this feature is disabled.


\subparagraph{Auto-size}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:auto-size}}
It is possible to automatically set the size of the image object to the image source’s width and height if enabled by the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_auto\_size(image, true)}} function.
If \sphinxstyleemphasis{auto size} is enabled then when a new file is set the object size is automatically changed. Later you can modify the size manually. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{auto size} is enabled by default if the image is not a screen


\subparagraph{Mosaic}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:mosaic}}
If the object size is greater then the image size in any directions then the image will be repeated like a mosaic.
It’s a very useful feature to create a large image from only a very narrow source.
For example, you can have a \sphinxstyleemphasis{300 x 1} image with a special gradient and set it as a wallpaper using the mosaic feature.


\subparagraph{Offset}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:offset}}
With \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_offset\_x(img, x\_ofs)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_offset\_y(img, y\_ofs)}} you can add some offset to the displayed image.
It is useful if the object size is smaller than the image source size.
Using the offset parameter a \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texture\_atlas}{Texture atlas} or a “running image” effect can be created by {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/animation::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Animating}}}} the x or y offset.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:styles}}
The images uses one style which can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_style(lmeter, LV\_IMG\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}. All the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.image}} properties are used:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{image.intense} intensity of recoloring (0..255 or \sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_OPA\_…})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{image.color} color for recoloring or color of the alpha indexed images

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{image.opa} overall opacity of image

\end{itemize}

When the Image object displays a text then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}} properties are used. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Label}}}} for more information.

The images’ default style is \sphinxstyleemphasis{NULL} so they \sphinxstylestrong{inherit the parent’s style}.


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/img:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{Image button (lv\_imgbtn)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:image-button-lv-imgbtn}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:overview}}
The Image button is very similar to the simple Button object. The only difference is it displays user-defined images in each state instead of drawing a button.
Before reading this please read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} section too.


\subparagraph{Image sources}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:image-sources}}
To set the image in a state the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_set\_src(imgbtn, LV\_BTN\_STATE\_..., \&img\_src)}} The image sources works the same as described in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image object}}}}.

If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMGBTN\_TILED}} is enabled in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} three sources can be set for each state:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
left

\item {} 
center

\item {} 
right

\end{itemize}

The \sphinxstyleemphasis{center} image will be repeated to fill the width of the object. Therefore with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMGBTN\_TILED}} you can set the width of the Image button while without it the width will be always the same as the image source’s width.


\subparagraph{States}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:states}}
The states also work like with Button object. It can be set with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_set\_state(imgbtn, LV\_BTN\_STATE\_...)}}.


\subparagraph{Toggle}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:toggle}}
The toggle feature can be enabled with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_set\_toggle(imgbtn, true)}}


\paragraph{Style usage}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:style-usage}}
Similarly to normal Buttons, Image buttons also have 5 independent styles for the 5 state. You can set them via: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_set\_style(btn, LV\_IMGBTN\_STYLE\_..., \&style)}}. The styles use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.image}} properties.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMGBTN\_STYLE\_REL} style of the released state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_rel}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMGBTN\_STYLE\_PR} style of the pressed state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_pr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMGBTN\_STYLE\_TGL\_REL} style of the toggled released state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_rel}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMGBTN\_STYLE\_TGL\_PR} style of the toggled pressed state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_pr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMGBTN\_STYLE\_INA} style of the inactive state. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_ina}}

\end{itemize}

When labels are created on a button, it’s a good practice to set the image button’s \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}} properties too. Because labels have \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style = NULL}} by default they inherit the parent’s (image button) style.
Hence you don’t need to create a new style for the label.


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:events}}
Besided the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Genreric events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} sent when the button is toggled.

\end{itemize}

Note that the generic input device related events (like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED}}) are sent in the inactive state too. You need to check the state with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_get\_state(btn)}} to ignore the events from inactive buttons.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP} Go to toggled state if toggling is enabled

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/DOWN} Go to non-toggled state if toggling is  enabled

\end{itemize}

Note that, as usual, the state of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} is translated to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED/PRESSING/RELEASED}} etc.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\label{\detokenize{object-types/imgbtn:example}}

\subsubsection{Keyboard (lv\_kb)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb:keyboard-lv-kb}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb:overview}}
The Keyboard object is a special {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/btnm::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button matrix}}}} with predefined keymaps and other features to realize a virtual keyboard to write text.


\subparagraph{Modes}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb:modes}}
The Keyboards have two modes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KB\_MODE\_TEXT} display letters, number, and special characters

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KB\_MODE\_NUM} display numbers, +/- sign and decimal dot

\end{itemize}

To set the mode use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb\_set\_mode(kb, mode)}}. The default is  \sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_KB\_MODE\_TEXT}


\subparagraph{Assign Text area}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb:assign-text-area}}
You can assign a {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/ta::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}} to the Keyboard to automatically put the clicked characters there.
To assign the Text area use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb\_set\_ta(kb, ta)}}.

The assigned Text area’s \sphinxstylestrong{cursor can be managed} by the keyboard: when the keyboard is assigned the previous Text area’s cursor will be hidden an the new’s will be shown.
When the keyboard is closed by the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Ok} or \sphinxstyleemphasis{Close} buttons the cursor also will be hidden. The cursor manager feature is enabled by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb\_set\_cursor\_manage(kb, true)}}. The default is not managed.


\subparagraph{New key map}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb:new-key-map}}
You can specify a new map (layout) for the keyboard with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb\_set\_map(kb, map)}}. and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb\_set\_ctrl\_map(kb, ctrl\_map)}}.
Learn more about in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{object-types/btnm::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button matrix}}}} object.
Keep in mind using following keywords will have the same effect as with the original map:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_SYMBOL\_OK} Apply

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{SYMBOL\_CLOSE} Close

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_SYMBOL\_LEFT} Move the cursor left

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_SYMBOL\_RIGHT} Move the cursor right

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{“ABC”} load the uppercase map

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{“abc”} load the lower case map

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{“Enter”} new line

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{“Bkps”} Delete on the left

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb:styles}}
The Keyboards work with 6 styles: a background and 5 button styles for each state.
You can set the styles with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb\_set\_style(btn, LV\_KB\_STYLE\_..., \&style)}}.
The background and the buttons use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties.
The labels use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}} properties of the buttons’ styles.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KB\_STYLE\_BG} Background style. Uses all \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties including \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding}} Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_pretty}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KB\_STYLE\_BTN\_REL} style of the released  buttons. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_rel}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KB\_STYLE\_BTN\_PR} style of the pressed buttons. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_pr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KB\_STYLE\_BTN\_TGL\_REL} style of the toggled released  buttons. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_rel}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KB\_STYLE\_BTN\_TGL\_PR} style of the toggled pressed  buttons. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_tgl\_pr}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KB\_STYLE\_BTN\_INA} style of the inactive  buttons. Default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_btn\_ina}}

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the keyboards:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} sent when the button is pressed/released or repeated after long press. The event data is set to ID of the pressed/released button.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_APPLY} the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Ok} button is clicked

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_CANCEL} the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Close} button is clicked

\end{itemize}

The keyboard has a \sphinxstylestrong{default event handler} callback called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb\_def\_event\_cb}}.
It handles the button pressing, map changing, the assigned Text area, etc.
You can completely replace it with your custom event handler but you can call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_kb\_def\_event\_cb}} at the beginning of your event handler to handle the same things as before.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/kb:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP/LEFT/RIGHT} To navigate among the buttons and elect one

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ENTER} To press/release the selected button

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{Label (lv\_label)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:label-lv-label}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/label::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:overview}}
The Labels are the basic objects to display text.


\subparagraph{Set text}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:set-text}}
You can modify the text in run-time at any time with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text(label, "New text")}}. It will allocate the text dynamically.

Labels are able to show text from a \sphinxstylestrong{static array}. Use: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_static\_text(label, char\_array)}}.
In this case, the text is not stored in the dynamic memory but the given array is used directly instead.
Keep in my the array can’t be a local variable which destroys when the function exits.

You can also use a \sphinxstylestrong{raw character array} as label text.
The array doesn’t have to be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}0}} terminated. In this case, the text will be saved to the dynamic memory.
To set a raw character array use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_array\_text(label, char\_array)}} function.


\subparagraph{Line break}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:line-break}}
You can use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}n}} to make line break. For example: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"line1\textbackslash{}nline2\textbackslash{}n\textbackslash{}nline4"}}


\subparagraph{Long modes}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:long-modes}}
The size of the label object can be automatically expanded to the text size or the text can be manipulated according to several long mode policies:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_EXPAND} Expand the object size to the text size (Default)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_BREAK} Keep the object width, break (wrap) the too long lines and expand the object height

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_DOTS} Keep the object size, break the text and write dots in the last line

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_SROLL} Keep the size and scroll the label back and forth

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_SROLL\_CIRC} Keep the size and scroll the label circularly

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_CROP} Keep the size and crop the text out of it.

\end{itemize}

You can specify the long mode with: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_long\_mode(label, LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_...)}}

It’s important to note that when a label is created and its test is set the label’s size already expanded to the text size.
In addition with the default \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_EXPAND}} \sphinxstyleemphasis{long mode} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width/height/size()}} has no effect.
So you need to change the \sphinxstyleemphasis{long mode} first and then set the size with  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width/height/size()}} .


\subparagraph{Text align}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:text-align}}
The label’s text can be aligned to the left, right or middle with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_align(label, LV\_LABEL\_ALIGN\_LEFT/RIGHT/CENTER)}}


\subparagraph{Draw background}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:draw-background}}
You can enable to draw a background for the label with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_body\_draw(label, draw)}}


\subparagraph{Text recolor}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:text-recolor}}
In the text, you can use commands to re-color parts of the text. For example: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"Write a \#ff0000 red\# word"}}.
This feature can be enabled individually for each label by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_recolor()}} function.

Note that, recoloring work only in a single line. I.e. there can’t be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}n}} in a recolored text or it can be wrapped by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_BREAK}} else the text in the new line won’t be recolored.


\subparagraph{Very long texts}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:very-long-texts}}
LittlevGL can effectively handle very long (\textgreater{} 40k characters) by saving some extra data (\textasciitilde{}12 bytes) to speed up drawing. To enable this feature set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_TXT\_HINT   1}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.


\subparagraph{Symbols}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:symbols}}
The labels can display symbols besides letters. Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/font::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Font}}}} section to learn more about the symbols.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:styles}}
The Label uses one style which can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_style(label, LV\_LABEL\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}. Form the style the following properties are used:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
all properties from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text}}

\item {} 
for background drawing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding}} will increase the size only visually, the real object’s size won’t be changed.

\end{itemize}

The labels’ default style is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} so they inherit the parent’s style.


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/label:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\subsubsection{LED (lv\_led)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/led:led-lv-led}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/led::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/led:overview}}
The LEDs are rectangle-like (or circle) object.


\subparagraph{Brightness}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/led:brightness}}
You can set their brightness with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_set\_bright(led, bright)}}. The brightness should be between 0 (darkest) and 255 (lightest).


\subparagraph{Toggle}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/led:toggle}}
Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_on(led)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_off(led)}} to set the brightness to a predefined  ON or OFF value.  The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_toggle(led)}} toggles between the ON and OFF state.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/led:styles}}
The LED uses one style which can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_set\_style(led, LV\_LED\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}.
To determine the appearance the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body}} properties are used.

The colors are darkened and shadow width is reduced at a lower brightness and gains its original value at brightness 255 to show a lighting effect.

The default style is: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_pretty\_color}}. Not that, the LED doesn’t really look like a LED with the default style so you should create your own style. See the example below.


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/led:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/led:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\paragraph{Example}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/led:example}}

\subsubsection{Line (lv\_line)}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/line:line-lv-line}}\label{\detokenize{object-types/line::doc}}

\paragraph{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/line:overview}}
The Line object is capable of drawing straight lines between a set of points.


\subparagraph{Set points}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/line:set-points}}
The points has to be stored in an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_point\_t}} array and passed to the object by the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_line\_set\_points(lines, point\_array, point\_cnt)}} function.


\subparagraph{Auto-size}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/line:auto-size}}
It is possible to automatically set the size of the line object according to its points.
You can enable it with the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_line\_set\_auto\_size(line, true)}} function.
If enabled then when the points are set the object’s width and height will be changed according to the maximal x and y coordinates among the points. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{auto size} is enabled by default.


\subparagraph{Invert y}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/line:invert-y}}
By deafult, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{y == 0} point is in the top of the object but you can invert the y coordinates with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_line\_set\_y\_invert(line, true)}}. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{y invert} is disabled by default.


\paragraph{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/line:styles}}
The Line uses one style which can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_line\_set\_style(led, LV\_LINE\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}} and it uses all \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.line}} properties.


\paragraph{Events}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/line:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{object-types/line:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.
